TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a matter which is of concern to some of my constituents; namely, the inordinate delays in hearing matters put to taxation boards of review. A case which has been put to me is from a constituent who has been involved in a jojoba plantation. The details do not matter very much. My constituent has gone into a scheme. The Commissioner of Taxation has made a certain determination. The taxpayer feels aggrieved and wishes to have that decision reviewed. It has emerged that 53,000 cases are awaiting review and the review boards are hearing something like 600 to 800 cases a year. On that basis my constituent's case might come up for determination in something like 55 years from now.

SPEECH.PARA: On the basis of the old idiom, justice delayed is justice denied, my taxpayer has a real concern. He may or may not have a case of merit. That is not for me to worry about. But he feels that he is in danger of suffering financial disadvantage. Processes are laid down by which he may appeal for review and he is unable to use them. They are blocked off because of such delays. I acknowledge immediately that the situation did not arise just this year. It has built up. However, I suggest to the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) that it may well have worsened in recent years. But, in any event, whatever the cause of the delay may have been and for however long it may have developed, I suggest that it is a very real barrier to justice being done in taxation areas.

In relation to this person we have had communications with the Australian Taxation Office. I am in possession of a letter from the Australian Taxation Office dated 25 September 1985 and addressed to this person, whose name I will not give. The letter states:
Dear Sir,
Income tax: Request for reference to a board of review
Years ended 30 June 1982 and 1983
Reference is made to your recent enquiry to the office of the Hon. Senator Peter Baume requesting further advice concerning your 1982 and 1983 objections.

At the outset it must be advised that, due to heavy workloads in our Appeals and Advisings Branch, it has not yet been possible to give effect to your request to refer the Commissioner's decision on the objections to a Board of Review.
It goes on to explain:

. . . before formal transfer of a reference to a Board of Review it has been the practice for some time to review the decision originally reached on the objection in the light of any additional information which the taxpayer may choose to supply . . .
I interpose that that may be all very well. But a right of review is conferred upon the taxpayer and it should be a right which the taxpayer can, in fact, exercise. The letter goes on to state:

In adopting this course and in fairness to other taxpayers who have also requested a reference to a Board of Review, cases are dealt with in the order in which they are received and it has not yet been possible to give your reference this attention. Some further time must necessarily lapse before this can be done.

It is my understanding that in the meantime the taxpayer is obliged to lodge a significant portion of the money which is under dispute with the Government even before the review is heard. The point I want to make to the Minister-I am not saying that it has arisen as a result of any administrative errors of this Government-is that if, in fact, something over 50,000 cases are awaiting hearing, if, in fact, the number being heard each year is small and if there is going to be a significant delay, taxpayers are not actually able to exercise their rights. It would not really matter if the number actually awaiting review were only 10,000. It would not really matter if the number being disposed of each year were, in fact, double what I have mentioned-maybe not 800 but 1,600-that would still be a five-year delay. Whatever the delay is, it is not fair. I therefore ask the Minister, not why did it occur but what can be done to get prompt hearing of these matters and to get the taxpayers the chance for a prompt exercise of their rights under taxation law?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Firstly, I will deal with the letter from which Senator Baume quoted. Of course, I have not actually seen a copy. That appears to be related to normal practice where the Australian Taxation Office asks the taxpayer whether he wishes to supply any additional information prior to the case going to the board of review. I think it is a very sensible procedure. On the matter of the backlog, I do not have the precise figures with me but from my recollection the backlog is of the order Senator Baume mentioned. It is continuing to increase, up to this stage. It is not quite as bad as it seems: I am advised that when one case is settled a large number of other cases frequently drop out because they are so close to being identical that they are resolved by the settlement of one case.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government is addressing the other question of the length of the backlog and the fact that, I think, it is still increasing, up to this stage. A submission has been prepared, and I expect it to be considered fairly soon, in which the question of both the number of boards and the composition of boards will be addressed. I expect an announcement to be made about that within the next few weeks, although I cannot guarantee it because it has not yet been considered by Cabinet. I am also told that, independently of the Cabinet submission, some new procedural practices have been adopted by the Taxation Office and the boards of review which it is expected will deal with the claims more efficiently and more quickly than has been the case in the past.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would be grateful if the Minister could advise me of any new administrative arrangements which are in place or are proposed to be put in place. I would be grateful also if, when a decision is made on the matter which I think the Minister said is the subject of submission at present, I could be advised of the outcome of that as well.
—The Treasurer (Mr Keating) will make a public statement, I expect.
—Could the Australian Taxation Office also let me know, in view of the fact that I have raised it here? I do not always see its public statements.
—I think the Treasurer should be able to do that. As to the other question, I think the Australian Taxation Office can provide written details of the new procedures which have been adopted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The point which Senator Peter Baume has just raised is really the tip of an iceberg which exists, as I think the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) will acknowledge, right through the administration of the Australian Taxation Office. Indeed, as I understand it there are very considerable problems in dealing with backlogs of work and in dealing with the welter of legislation which the Government is bringing forward as a result of its recent tax package. In the light of the lack of information which has been forthcoming from the Government about its proposed timetable for putting down legislation for debate in the Parliament on the new tax package, and in particular I mention the capital gains tax, the fringe benefits tax and the legislation on negative gearing-it now being almost five months since the announcement was originally made-I ask whether the Government is in a position to give us a timetable as to legislation and, indeed, some kind of indication as to when the Parliament will be dealing with it.

SPEECH.PARA: I might just outline the case for that because I think it is important to recognise that the legislation that the Government intends to put in place as a result of the tax package is very complex. I think that the Government recognises that. Also, there are many uncertain areas in the legislation. The statement that has been made by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) really gives us very little indication of what will be taxed and what will not be taxed. I instance the capital gains tax because I think the Minister will acknowledge that during Question Time in this place and during questions addressed to the Treasurer in the House of Representatives, we quite frequently get interpretations of what will be covered by the legislation, but it is always subject to the qualification that the Government has not yet finalised its view about these things. The degree of uncertainty that is growing in the community on these various matters, I hope the Minister agrees, is becoming very widespread. Indeed, if we are to wait another five or six months before we get the legislation on the tax package before we have a chance to even assess what it is that is going to be subject to tax, it is going to be an intolerable situation for the conduct of business by ordinary businesses out there in the market-place.

The point that I wanted to make following that is that I believe there is a need, as a matter of policy and of administration, for any government to be able to provide detailed legislation on its intentions in the tax area. I think we can draw the distinction between legislation that is drawn to outlaw loopholes in law that become evident through the increasing use of tax avoidance devices and things of that kind. Should statements be made at a particular time, it is reasonable that there might be some delay in the actual preparation of legislation, but at least people are put on notice that that loophole will be closed. That is an entirely different situation from the situation which we face now. The Government, having announced a total new tax regime in many areas, has not clearly indicated what is going to be subject to tax. Indeed, that is still going to be the situation, as I understand it, for some months to come. I think the Government should appreciate that distinction and make sure that in future when it is setting out changes to the whole tax structure, as opposed to some parts of the legislation, it brings in the legislation with its package.

I recall a major change to the tax regime that resulted from the Ligertwood Commonwealth Committee on Taxation recommendations as far back as 1964. If my memory proves me correct, I think it was 22 October 1964 that the Government introduced a whole package of changes, where the statements made in the Parliament were done at the same time as the legislation affecting the changes was introduced. Indeed, that was fairly quickly followed by statements from the Taxation Commissioner as to how the law would be administered thereafter. I believe that is the ideal way for the Government to handle situations of this kind. Indeed, it is an extraordinary imposition on the community for people to face taxation on various types of new defined income, as the Government now has done through its tax package, and have no clear indication as to whether certain transactions and certain kinds of income will be subject to tax.

TALK.START.PARA: —I suppose in an ideal world what Senator Messner said would be correct. I do not think it is accurate to say that people do not know what is going to be taxed and what is not going to be taxed. In general that is well known. In very fine detail it is probably not known, but there is nothing unique about that, even for tax laws which have been enacted. Indeed, the fact that it is not always unequivocally clear in fine detail is one of the major reasons why we have so many appeals going to taxation boards of review, a question which Senator Peter Baume raised a couple of minutes ago. I ask Senator Messner not to take this as a definitive answer, but to the best of my knowledge the fringe benefits legislation will be introduced before this spring Budget session ends and the rest of the legislation will be introduced in the autumn session. I will see whether the Treasurer (Mr Keating) has anything to add to that. To the best of my knowledge that is the case.
—Do you mean the entertainment tax as opposed to fringe benefits?

—Yes, I think that is part of the fringe benefits tax. I lodge the caveat: Do not take that as a definitive answer. It is not without precedent for legislation to be many months behind an announcement. Senator Messner has mentioned that it sometimes happens when loopholes are closed. There is at least one other occasion not relating to the closing of a loophole that I can remember, and that was the announcement in July 1982 of major changes to the depreciation allowance for plant, which was announced by the last Government. That legislation was not, in fact, enacted by that Government at all; it was enacted by the present Government in the autumn of 1983. Likewise, a range of tax amendments and concessions announced with the 1982 Budget, not related to the closing of loopholes, was not legislated in 1982 at all. It was legislated by this Government in March or April 1983.

—I raise a matter that is of some concern to me. It has been reported to me that the Australian Taxation Office mislays or loses at least 10 per cent of its files each year. That seemed an amazing figure. Can the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) place a figure on the actual loss rate of tax returns, documents and files? Even if it is one-tenth of that figure, what type of steps are being taken to improve the capture and retention of such important information within the Office?

—I do not know where Senator Vigor heard that. I think common sense should tell us that it is not true. I am advised that the Australian Taxation Office does not believe it loses any files at all. It acknowledges mislaying files from time to time. The Taxation Office also believes, being suspicious, I suppose, that some taxpayers claim to have lodged returns when in fact they have not. I guess in that sort of circumstance there is no way of actually determining with certainty whether the Taxation Office has lost a file or whether taxpayers, in what they perceive to be their own interests, claim they have done something which in fact they have not done.

—As I understand it, one of the problems under the existing taxation Act is that a document is presumed to have been received by a taxpayer if it has been posted by the Australian Taxation Office but that the same type of presumption does not apply in the other direction. Apparently, under the tax legislation if something has been posted by the Office it is deemed to have been received by the taxpayer but the taxpayer does not have the same presumption in his favour. In the light of current statistics concerning the number of documents lost in the post and with the current industrial problems in Australia Post, I ask whether the Government is planning to do anything about the situation. Lost mail may be one of the reasons for the comment about mislaid documents.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —In regard to documents despatched from the Australian Taxation Office, I suppose it cannot guarantee that such documents have actually been delivered because the possibility of their being mislaid or even stolen in transit exists. However, independent records are kept of documents which have been put into the Australia Post bags. I understand some special postal arrangements are available to the Taxation Office. So although I guess one cannot guarantee with certainty that documents have been delivered, one can be as certain as one can be in an uncertain world that they have been posted.

SPEECH.PARA: The other point related to the assertion that a taxpayer's claim to have posted a document is treated differently from the Tax Office's claim. To be realistic I think we must acknowledge that the individuals working in the Taxation Office could not conceivably have any personal motive for making inaccurate claims, whereas from time to time taxpayers do have a personal incentive to do so. Without wishing to cast aspersions on individuals, one must assume that on average the officials of the Taxation Office are more likely to be telling the truth at all times than are taxpayers. In regard to the final question, I do not know whether the procedures in the Taxation Office are under review or whether consideration is being given to making them more effective. I will see whether the Treasurer has any response to that.

TALK.START.PARA: —My next question relates to the Australian Bureau of Statistics. The Bureau in its recent advertisements for field interviewers required that applicants have a driver's licence and access to a car. I ask: Is this the result of Government policy or is it an administrative decision of the Bureau? Will the Government examine this apparent discrimination against one sector of the community, particularly as it relates to the unemployed, who may not be able to get the job because at the time of their application they may not run a car? My next question, also concerning the Bureau of Statistics, relates more to its central operation. The Bureau in its latest annual report mentions that it is reliant on obsolete computer equipment and that there are long delays in getting its central computing installation fully operational. The report also mentions the need for a more extensive application of small scale technology. We often get reports on surveys up to two or three years after the event and sometimes the information may no longer be politically or socially relevant. We can get printouts of statistics but in most cases these are not available for on-line electronic interrogation. Is the Government examining how to make more efficient use of available resources within the Bureau of Statistics?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a definitive answer to Senator Vigor's first question. That was an administrative decision. I will see what response the Treasurer (Mr Keating) can provide to the other questions.

SPEECH.PARA: Progress reported.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Walsh) agreed to:
That, unless otherwise ordered, until 2 p.m. today, matters of public interest may be discussed by senators, provided that no senator shall speak for more than 15 minutes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is imperative that the new electoral boundaries in Queensland be discussed in the Senate. At stake are not only the democratic rights of the citizens of Queensland but also Australia's international reputation. Madam Acting Deputy President, from time to time issues raised in the Senate proceed to a vote. When that occurs my vote is equal to yours and your vote is equal to anyone else's; that is, the vote of any senator is worth the same as that of any other senator. In a democracy we expect that a similar situation should prevail for those who elect governments. Each citizen's vote should be equal to those of his or her fellow citizens. In a democracy there is nothing more basic than a person's right to vote. As well, there is nothing more fundamental than the value or worth of one person's vote being equal to that of another person's vote.

SPEECH.PARA: Sadly, this situation does not exist in Queensland. Even before the redistribution which was announced last week, Queensland citizens did not have equality of voting, yet now the situation is worse. The latest piece of electoral legislation and the boundaries which have been drawn up under it must represent the greatest electoral dishonesty in Queensland's political history. Citizens of Queensland have been shocked by the new electoral boundaries, even though over the years the Queensland people have become almost immune to the manipulation of boundaries to achieve certain electoral results. But on this occasion the minority National Party Government has gone too far. The people will not accept such blatant cheating. They want a fair go, a fair go so that the people of Queensland have an equality of votes; a fair go for any party to be able to form a government if it gains a majority of votes; a fair go so that any party which does not obtain majority electoral support cannot govern in its own right. They want an electoral system of which they can be proud, not one which will tarnish Australia's image overseas.

Before the latest redistribution in Queensland, the electoral system was grossly malapportioned. In other words, the number of electors in the various electorates deviated from the principle of one vote one value. The malapportionment was due to a zonal system which segregated voters into different geographic groups and placed different values on votes cast in different zones. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a table showing the zonal system following the 1977 redistribution in Queensland together with the number of seats and the average number of voters per seat in the various zones. The data in this table and in another, to which I shall refer later, have been checked by the statistics section of the Parliamentary Library.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have not seen it.

—I will show it to the honourable senator. The table records that Queensland electors were segregated into four zones. One is termed south-east, another provincial cities, the third is named western and far northern and the fourth is termed country. The table also reveals that the value of a vote in the western and far northern zone was almost double that of a vote in an electorate in the south-east zone which includes the State capital, Brisbane. What is not shown in the table is that the ratio of the highest to the lowest enrolment was 2.3:1. One vote, one value seemed to be an unheard of principle. The deliberate malapportionment brought about by the 1977 redistribution called out for correction, but anyone who hoped that a future redistribution would lead towards an equality of voting was disappointed. I now return to my request to have that table incorporated in Hansard.

TALK.START.PARA: —Since the 1983 State election the National Party has, for the first time, governed without the assistance of a co-alition partner. After that election it had 43 members of the 82-member Parliament. This included the two Liberals who set aside their principles, if any, and switched to the National Party immediately after the election. It was against this background of a narrow majority that the National Party Government this year introduced its Electoral Districts Bill. Amongst other things, the Bill determined that the same zonal system would continue and increase the number of seats in the State House by seven. There were, perhaps, a few optimists in Queensland who thought that the 1985 redistribution would result in a fair electoral system, a system which would allow the fair go that I mentioned only a short time ago. The optimists were wrong. As my colleague Senator Jones pointed out to me and even remarked in the Senate, the remarks of the Premier during the debate on the Electoral Districts Bill should have been a warning of what was to come. I seek leave now to incorporate in Hansard a table showing the zonal system following the 1985 redistribution in Queensland together with the same data as shown in the previously incorporated table.

TALK.START.PARA: —This table indicates that the 1985 redistribution has resulted in a greater degree of malapportionment than that of the 1977 redistribution. A vote in the western and far northern zone is now worth more than twice as much as a vote in the south-east zone and almost twice that of the provincial zone. The gap between the average number of voters in the south-east zone and the country zone has widened considerably.

SPEECH.PARA: Whilst the principal effect of the zonal system is to produce a malapportioned electoral system it could also be regarded as a gerrymander in its own right. By gerrymander, I mean a system where boundaries are drawn in such a way as to serve a partisan advantage. The Queensland zonal system reduces the value of some citizens' votes and increases the value of others. Almost all of the electorates where the value of a vote has been enhanced are held by the ruling National Party. That cannot by any stretch of the imagination be regarded as a mere coincidence. The continued use of the zonal system, together with its unequal weighting of electors is nothing but a disgusting exercise in self-preservation on the part of the National Party in Queensland.

I shall read to the Senate a quotation from a member of the Queensland Parliament about a zonal system but not mention the name of the speaker until the end of the quote. The grammatical error in the quotation appears in the original Hansard. It states:

Truly, these are grave days for the people of Queensland, not so much because of the enemy without as because of the enemy within. Little do the people realise the grave injustice that is silently being inflicted upon them. In a most subtle way their freedom to select the Government they want to represent them are being taken away from them . . . In this legislation the people are being given the right of voting, admittedly, but the odds are so greatly against them that to achieve the results they desire is impossible because the predetermined zones and the numbers set out will mean nothing but that the majority will be ruled by the minority.

The Speaker was not the Leader of the Queensland Opposition, or the Leader of the Liberal Party. The speaker was no other than the now Premier of Queensland, Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen. He said this as a backbencher on 29 March 1949 when the zonal system was being debated in the Queensland Parliament. How relevant and how prophetic his words seem today. Nevertheless, it is necessary to highlight one aspect of that quotation. The 1985 redistribution is not a subtle subversion of representative democracy in Queensland; it has all the subtlety of a head-on collision.

I mentioned earlier that a grossly malapportioned system has resulted from the 1985 redistribution. I also suggested that the zonal system could be regarded as a gerrymander in its own right. If so, there are two dimensions of gerrymander in the redistribution because a further system of gerrymander overlays the zonal system. We are looking at boundary distortion and manipulation to advantage one party at the expense of others. Perhaps the most blatant manipulation of boundaries occurred with the small Aboriginal community of Wujal Wujal in far north Queensland. Wujal Wujal was transferred by the Act to the western and far northern zone from the provincial city zone electorate held by the Minister for Administrative Services, Mr Tenni. The reason for making Wujal Wujal a landlocked island wholly surrounded by Mr Tenni's electorate, but not part of it, was the community's apparent audacity in failing to give the Minister political support. Just over 66 per cent of Wujal Wujal voters cast their votes for the Australian Labor Party at the last State election.

I am aware that the South African system of apartheid has many sympathisers amongst the National Party. They must be pleased with this neat piece of electoral isolation. Wujal Wujal is a vivid example of Queensland-style apartheid. There are many examples of manipulated boundaries, some of which would make Governor Gerry of Massachusetts, the father of gerrymandering, blush. However, I shall leave examples of those because of the limitations of time on this debate. It is also worth mentioning, however, that there is a degree of malapportionment within the provincial city zone. Five different areas are treated separately: Bundaberg, central Queensland, Townsville, Cairns and Mackay. The average enrolments in each of these areas vary. Of the 13 electorates in this zone the highest enrolment is 20,837 and the lowest 15,959. It is perhaps of no suprise that the electorate with the lowest enrolment is Barron River, currently held by Mr Tenni.

Lest it be thought that I have been overstating this case, honourable senators should allow me to quote from the publication Inside Canberra, dated 8 November 1985. Whilst I do not agree with all the claims made, they are an indication of how bad one commentator sees the situation to be. The publication states:

Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen's new electoral boundaries give him a hard core of nearly 50 seats out of the 89 in the Queensland Parliament. The Liberals have a hard core of 10 to 12 and were pleasantly surprised not to be wiped out. Labor could only count on 31 seats (or 35 per cent of the total) with its 1983 election figure of 45 per cent. It is now polling only 40 per cent and would drop to just above 20 seats. It would need 55.5 per cent of the vote to win a majority of seats in Queensland.
Referring to what it stated as zonal malapportionment, the article continued:
It gives Labor very few chances of winning the swag of new seats in the fastest growing area of Queensland-the conurbations running north, south, east and west of Brisbane along the major highways.
Even though I know of no conurbation running east of Brisbane, this is a sound assessment.

I now turn to the damage an electoral system like this has on Australia's international reputation. During the year, Australia has emphasised its long held repugnance of the lack of political rights for a vast number of black South Africans. Although we are a nation of only 15 million people, we do not hesitate to criticise other countries who do not afford basic human rights to their citizens. Indeed, we should not hesitate to do so. But will other countries take us seriously if we are seen to use an electoral system which denies electoral justice to a great section of the citizens of the third most populated state in Australia? We could be told, and rightly so, to go home and clear up our own backyard.

This afternoon I have outlined certain aspects of the malapportioned and manipulated electoral boundaries in Queensland. I have not indicated what action the Federal Government should take other than to condemn what has occurred in Queensland. I have, however, on a previous occasion publicly stated that the Federal Government must take urgent action to ensure that the principle of one vote, one value for all legislatures in Australia is enshrined in legislation or in the Constitution. That is another matter which I expect will be debated some time in the future. Democracy, although the best form of government, is a fragile system. Unfortunately, the redistribution in Queensland is not doing anything to uphold that fragile system. It adversely affects the democratic rights of citizens in that State. It also has the potential of eroding the high international reputation that Australia enjoys.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have listened with interest to Senator Colston's comments and I do not want in any way to enter into a defence of what most of us would believe is indefensible. But I am reminded of certain lines, the author of which I cannot remember. The merit of the lines is in the words that are spoken and not in the author, so I will remind the Senate of them. The lines are:

SPEECH.PARA: Tell me not, in mournful numbers,
Life is but an empty dream!
For the soul is dead that slumbers,
And things are not what they seem.

I ask Senator Colston to consider a subject that I will raise today, that is that any parliament elected in a democratic way by one vote, one value still does not achieve everything. That may not be all; things are not always what they seem in a democracy. I draw Senator Colston's attention to a speech by Lord Hailsham entitled `How free should we be' in which he drew a distinction between what he chose to call a centralised democracy and a different sort of democracy that believed in freedom under law. He said:

The clue to the difference between the two doctrines lies in a simple contrast. One asserts the right of the bare majority to do what it will. It believes it right that such a majority should impose on the entire community whatever laws or whatever structures it pleases, guided only by what it conceives to be the general good. The other denies that very right. On the contrary, it asserts that minorities and individuals have rights and interests which cannot be overridden by a majority however large and it will go on to claim that all government, whether popular or authoritarian, is subject to inherent limitations which it can only ignore at its peril.

Senator Colston wanted a copy of that speech. I would be happy to provide it for him. My comments today centre on the roles of and relationship between the Parliament and the media. Being a politician, albeit a relative novice in the area, I have a strong desire to win elections and see the policies that I believe in put into practice. That would be achieved much more easily if politicians on my side of this chamber were, in a sense, bedfellows of the media. But I do not believe that it would ever be appropriate to allow that situation to arise. I am quite sure that the relationship between politicians and the media is now, and should remain, one of tension and mutual suspicion.

Complicity between those who have power and those who tell the country about how that power is exercised is always a danger to any democracy. The journalist's job is to tell people things. It is to tell people what is happening in parliament; to acquire information, analyse that information and convey it, in whatever form he chooses, to the journal, radio station or television program he works for. Politicians do not always believe that when this activity takes place it is in their interests. Where media coverage is to eventuate, politicians understandably would like it to take place on their terms, in their way and, if possible, under their control. This, of course, is not in the interests of any democracy. Frequently we hear politicians blanketing their policies under the guise of their being in the public interest. Much damage has been done to democracy by politicians claiming to do things in the national interest simply because that individual politician, his party or his government, wishes to get a certain matter through the Parliament and therefore claims this blanket coverage of being in the national interest. We must rely on the media to be our watchdog, to provide a peephole under the blanket, to use a magnifying glass to tell the country exactly what is happening under the guise of public interest.

Rudyard Kipling, I am led to believe, invented the saying about newspapers that was once put in Stanley Baldwin's mouth. He said that they have power without responsibility; the prerogative of the harlot through the ages. I am not at all sure that that is a fair comment, but it is one I think we should bear in mind. The media has a role in informing the public what happens in the Parliament. Comments such as Kelly's and observations by satirists such as Ian Warden, amusing though he may be, sometimes I think ignore the reality that the media is a part of our political equation and they cannot stand outside it without responsibility. Nor should they come so close that they become bedfellows with the politicians as I have said. But I think we should acknowledge that we are in the same arena more frequently than we do. The Canadian experience with the introduction of television to the coverage of Parliament brought to light many of the misgivings, perceptions and realities of parliamentary democracy in the electronic age that we now live in. Madam Speaker Lapointe of the Canadian Senate, speaking in Canberra in 1978, said:

One of the most effective arguments heard in Canada for televising Parliament's business was that the time had come to take Parliament to the people. For too long its debates and crises had been filtered through the mouths and eyes of others. Not all those others were impartial, detached or objective observers. Programme editors, for example, decided which interviewers, commentators, academics or politicians would monopolize the screen to portray their version of events. Programme editors, we know, are not responsible to any electorate.

In my view, the media often appears only too willing to pass adverse judgment of Parliament and, perhaps, this chamber in particular. In the wake of the 1983 National Economic Summit the noted political journalist, Paul Kelly, wrote in the Sydney Morning Herald. He said:

The national Economic Summit is like a shot in the arm for a political reporter who has sat in the gallery for the past decade watching the decline of Parliament. The truth is that in two days the summit meeting has produced not only a fruitful debate about the economy, but offers the prospect of bringing parties closer together. This is something that has not happened in the Parliament for many years. It is a measure of the decay of our parliamentary system and is also a condemnation of the quality of our Parliamentarians.

That is a comment from some time ago. Various senators and members and, indeed, members of the public may have read Ian Warden's article in the Canberra Times on Monday entitled `Knitting in the Land of Nod'. For those who have not read it I can tell them briefly that it was a cry of delight that he was to be relieved from the tedium and boredom of reporting Senate Question Time. He said that the `authentic voice of the Senate was just a dreary lullaby'. We should congratulate Ian Warden for pointing out what he sees as a problem that this chamber faces if it is to continue to have the credibility that it now has in the public eye. But, at the same time, I think it is fair to point out to Mr Warden that this house of review is not meant always to have the glitter of the gladiators in another place. With respect to those gladiators I could say, perhaps, that they are like wrestlers with a pre-staged outcome-every blow and kick being choreographed many days before the performance takes place.

TALK.START.PARA: —And the result fixed.

—And the result fixed as Senator Puplick says. I can offer some reasons for what I believe is a real decline in the role of Parliament, not just one that is perceived by the media. There is the growth of much more disciplined parties than we have seen in the past; there are increased expectations of bureaucracy, there is the growing role of outside groups which, as we all know, are outside the arms of government; and there are the media, the trade unions, the multinational business corporations and the National Farmers Federation. I could go on but I will not. Of course, there is also the advance of complex international technologies. Professor Reid, now His Excellency, has identified a few more of these problems. He says:

SPEECH.PARA: The problems of Parliament also arise from its inherent division; not only is it divided by the federal constitution into two nominally powerful, and often conflicting, Houses: each constitutent House accommodates competing factions-each of which is usually divided between leaders and led . . . and, following the Westminster style of government, both Houses grant important priorities in debate and decision-making to executive Ministers of state.

This has been cited as a problem that has facilitated the decline of Parliament. Professor Reid goes on to identify seven things that the Senate has done to ensure that it achieves, in one way, more than the House of Representatives in terms of survival. He writes:
Where the House of Representatives has failed the Senate has succeeded.

The first thing he points to is that since 1932 the Senate has borne the Parliament's responsibility for the scrutiny of the expanding volume of regulations and ordinances. He further points out that since 1970-71, the Senate has been bearing most of the burden of providing a parliamentary oversight of the Executive. He mentions, thirdly, the Senate's role in estimates of expenditure. He refers to the Senate's reference of Bills to small committees. It would be, perhaps, inappropriate for me to comment at this stage on how few Bills are actually referred to committees. He says that only in the Senate is there an attempt to subject annual reports of commissions, boards and instrumentalities to systematic committee scrutiny and only the Senate has shown a willingness to submit its own administration to a parliamentary inquiry. When he wrote the article I think it was true that only the Senate had produced a record of its voluminous precedence.

In addition to the matters that I have raised about the decline of Parliament and what the Senate has done to bolster its own role, I should make some comment about the role of the chamber. One of the most frequent criticisms that I hear from visitors to this place is how few people are in the chamber. I believe that this lack of interest in the chamber is dangerous. If the chamber is occupied only by people who wish to make their speeches and then depart a certain sense of debate is lost. I offer the opinion that too few of those who are quick to pass judgments on those in this chamber recognise that members of parliament, both the House of Representatives and Senate, now spend a much larger portion of their working time in ways which have very little to do with the concept of parliament as the great forum of the nation. Instead of a parliamentarian being his or her constituent's representative in Canberra, he or she has become an interpreter of government policy back to the electorate and a mediator between the electorate and various manifestations of government. Perhaps it is unkind to suggest that the media all too readily accept the system as it is. It provides for them an easy target, namely the limited number of members of the Executive and the back bench members who, being a somewhat nomadic flock, are perhaps more difficult to capture to portray adequately the reality of the back bench to the public. Nonetheless, this is a goal that I believe the media should take upon themselves.

In June or July, Australia was treated to a number of full page advertisements by a gentleman known as Mr John Leard. These advertisements received an enormous amount of coverage. The media said finally someone was prepared to stand up and say the things about Australia that our lazy politicians should have been saying all along. Mr Leard got much more space than he actually paid for in the media comment that followed. As a consequence of that comment, I chose to inquire from the library what sort of speeches had been made on four of the topics that Mr Leard used in his advertisement. It may interest senators to know that on the question of the national debt, in 1983-84, 47 senators had addressed the matter and in 1985 until late May 32 had. With respect to deregulation of the labour market, the figures were six and 18 respectively. On the question of government expenditure, in 1983-84, 20 senators had addressed the matter and in 1985, 20 again. Several weeks ago a debate on youth unemployment received very little coverage in the media. I believe it should have. It is my view that the media and the Press gallery in the Senate have a responsibility not only to report those things which have some glitter about them and are of a starring nature, but also to criticise Parliament when the speeches are so boring that no one can be bothered to listen.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McIntosh Sen G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to take this opportunity to say a few words on the Irian Jayan refugee situation. As honourable senators are aware, some 10,000 West Irians crossed the rugged jungle border from Irian Jaya into Papua New Guinea almost two years ago. Despite the fact that this number represents almost one per cent of the total Melanesian population of Irian Jaya and was well in excess of the relatively few border people who normally cross back and forth, the Australian Government at first tried to claim that the situation was normal. It was not long before we were insisting that it was a bilateral problem between PNG and Indonesia.

SPEECH.PARA: One would have thought that the arrival of eight West Irian canoe people on Australian soil in the past few months would have been ultimate proof that we cannot keep on ignoring what is happening inside Irian Jaya or that we can keep on escaping our international responsibilities when an obvious violation of human rights is being perpetrated in our immediate region.

The media coverage and Government statements on the situation of the refugees have tended to concentrate on what is to happen to the refugees. For example, will they stay in PNG? If they are to return, how soon will they do so? Will some have to go to a third country? If so, which countries? There can be no lasting solution to these questions until the immediate causes of the flight of thousands of people from the country is recognised.

The first question we must ask in any discussion about the refugees is: What is happening inside Irian Jaya to cause such mass migration? Ever since the Indonesians took control of the territory from the Dutch in the early 1960s, the picture has been one of subjugation of a people. The so-called act of free choice in 1969, though recognised by the United Nations, was simply manipulated by Jakarta to ensure that West Irian remained part of Indonesia. The Melanesian people have been continually subjected to programs to change their culture, to bring them out of the Stone Age, as one Indonesian Minister so paternalistically put it. In addition, people such as Arnold Ap have been shot in cold blood for the subversive activity of trying to preserve the Melanesian culture. Indonesia has embarked on the transmigration of Javanese into West Irian and intends to settle some 900,000 people in the province. Many of these transmigrants will be placed along the border in the north and south areas. There are already stories of forced acquisition of land by the Government to make way for the transmigrants. The local people, faced with the loss of their land, are also faced with being a minority in their own land. Not surprisingly, they are increasingly prepared to support the armed resistance which is generally referred to as the OPM as it tries tactics to resist transmigration. It is a great irony that the transmigration program, which has been implemented to dilute the Melanesian population, is having the effect of strengthening West Papuan nationalism.

These are the issues that must be understood before we consider solutions to the refugee problem. The harsh and insensitive nature of the Indonesian regime has led to a mixture of spontaneous and organised resistance from the local population. The OPM has existed inside the territory since 1960. There is plenty of evidence to suggest that it is not a single, centrally organised movement but it seems certain that the different groups around the country have a common aim. The last 20 years have been marked by spontaneous uprisings in specific areas in response to particular policies and actions of the Indonesian Administration. The Indonesian response to this resistance has been mainly a military one. Claims about Indonesian military operations in Irian Jaya are difficult to confirm but those of us familiar with the sad fate of the East Timorese have little difficulty in believing accounts of gross cruelty by Indonesian troops inside Irian Jaya. However, these military responses have not stopped resistance. If anything, West Papuan nationalism seems to be growing. It is primarily because of the indestructibility of West Papuan resistance that the Indonesian Government has intensified its official transmigration programs. As I have said, it is a mistake to see the future of the refugees or the border problem as the basic issues. The refugees are simply the visible sign of what is happening inside Irian Jaya. We can only guess what is happening to people who live far from the border, who have been forced off their land or forced into resettlement villages to make way for the transmigrants.

Various claims have been made about the reasons why over 10,000 Irianese have fled into PNG. Some certainly fled in fear from the Jayapura area following the Indonesian military responses to the abortive OPM uprising in early 1984. Further south, people crossed because of harrassment or fear of harassment by the Indonesian forces. In part, this harassment went hand in hand with the implementation of the transmigration program. Some may have crossed to make a statement about the seriousness of what is happening in the territory or to draw international attention to the situation. At least some have crossed to avoid being caught in the OPM-Indonesian fights. What can clearly be said is that people, particularly Melanesian village people, do not leave their land without strong reasons for doing so. It must be remembered that 96 refugees died of starvation in the camps rather than go back to the other side of the border. Those who claim that the refugees fled in response to OPM propaganda, fail firstly, to acknowledge the experience that these people have had with the Indonesian military, and, secondly to explain why the refugees have stayed so long. Those who argue that the refugees are there purely for propaganda purposes also fail to concede that the longer the refugees remain in PNG, the more likely it is that their land will be taken in their absence by the Indonesian Administration for the transmigration program.

Until recently the official position of the PNG Government was that the issue of the border crossers and refugees was a bilateral issue between itself and Indonesia. It is probable that sections within the PNG Government would like to force the return of a great percentage of the Irianese in the border camps. Fortunately, the PNG Government is restrained from doing this because of an enormous popular sympathy for the Irianese inside PNG. What the PNG Government will do about the refugees is still a matter of conjecture. Such incidents as the recent forced repatriation of 12 Irianese, with probable OPM connections, have happened before but they are a cause for alarm amongst defenders of human rights. The most recent statement from the PNG Government that it is trying to internationalise the problem is, in my view, a long overdue and important step.

The Australian position on the refugees has been to cop out by saying that it is not our problem. Our official position in late 1984 was that `the best long term solution . . . is for the people to return voluntarily in safety and dignity'. Unfortunately, there is little evidence that Australia has acted to facilitate this objective. Foreign Minister Hayden told the PNG Government on 6 November that Australia would not take any of the refugees into Australia and that we have made a significant contribution in humanitarian aid for the refugees in the PNG camps. It is prepared to consider helping PNG resettle genuine refugees in PNG, to find third countries to take some of the refugees and seek further United Nations assistance for PNG. The arrival of five West Irianese on Boigu, an Australian island off the PNG coast, has, however, put the cat amongst the pigeons. The Government quickly stated that no Irianese reaching Australia in this way would be allowed to stay here. This policy, said the Government, was to discourage the `draw effect' or flood of people into Australia.

At this stage it is certainly worth noting that the Government has not so far been prepared to concede that there might have been a legitimate reason for leaving Irian Jaya. One might be excused for gaining an impression from the media and from the Government statements that somehow the Papua New Guinean Government was to blame. I cannot explain the apparently hard line position of the Australian Government in what seems to be a clear cut human rights question. We cannot turn a blind eye to what is happening inside Irian Jaya. The root cause for the refugee problem is the policies of the Indonesian Government in the province. At the very least, Australia should insist on a modification of Indonesian Government activities in Irian Jaya. The first thing that must be tackled is the scale and implementation of the transmigration program. This is not simply an internal matter for Indonesia. The transmigration program is, at least in part, responsible for what is now, by definition, an international refugee problem. Australia should insist that if people are to return to Irian Jaya they should do so voluntarily under internationally agreed conditions, for example, under conditions of continual monitoring by the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees. In the case of the Irianese who do not want to return, Australia should promote an international scheme to settle the refugees in this region.

Events in West Irian are of regional concern. Australia is in a position to play a key role in this issue. It is also in a position to urge on the Indonesian Government a modification of the policies which are responsible for the problem. If we are not prepared to tackle the root causes of the issue our moral responsibilities to assist the victims of events in Irian Jaya are even greater.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take this opportunity today to pass a few remarks on the redistribution in Queensland proposed by the National Party Government. The efforts of the National Party-which, I might add, are almost certain to be successful, given the weakness and ineptitude of the Liberal Party in Queensland-to effect yet another and even more far reaching gerrymander of State electoral boundaries are, given the nature of the Government in Queensland, quite obscene. The proposal, as Senator Colston has said, provides the well-discredited National Party with an electoral majority if it manages to harvest a mere 35 per cent of the vote. It is a knife in the back of democracy not only in Queensland but also in Australia as a whole. We must not sit back in the Senate and regard Queensland as being somewhere else, or something to laugh at and then forget. Sir Johannes Bjelke-Petersen is not a joke figure. He is well and truly beyond any form of joke-he is a dangerous man.

SPEECH.PARA: Queensland represents a large part of Australia. It is the third largest State in Australia in terms of population and the second largest in terms of size. The rest of Australia cannot isolate itself from the outrages perpetrated by the Queensland Government under the guise of Queensland democracy. No one wants a State rights confrontation but, at the same time, one single State government cannot be allowed to continue, year after year, prostituting the basic parliamentary procedures of the entire nation. It is pointless talking about constitutional responsibilities in relation to Queensland as it is today, or Australia, while Queensland remains as it is. It is pointless even thinking of individual rights and equalities. The latest redistribution is designed to smash the electoral voice of some 65 per cent of the voting public, or even slightly more, to allow a minority party, Sir Johannes Bjelke-Petersen's National Party, to govern in its own right on a vote of 35 per cent or even slightly less.

In simple terms, the proposal demands, through this electoral villainy, one-party control over Queensland on a vote that could be one or more percentage points behind the 36 per cent it achieved in the 1974 State election which reduced the Australian Labor Party temporarily, and democratically disastrously, to a cricket team without a twelfth man in a parliament of 82. A report was released by the three commissioners who handled the maps within a highly rigid, totally unjust four-zonal system thrust upon it under the terms of reference given to them by Sir Johannes Bjelke-Petersen and his Cabinet. The whole idea of the exercise was to put the electoral boundaries in kilter-to make the imbalances brought about by population changes more fair and realistic. What are we confronted with in this so-called redistribution? Let me give an example. A seat called Balonne in the Bjelke-Petersen back blocks of Queensland has a handful of electors-a mere 8,162. Perhaps they could recruit a few kangaroos and for that matter, a few emus. At the other end of the scale is the seat of Townsville East, in the midst of a highly populated provincial city, where 20,837 voters will jostle with each other to cast a vote for the Australian Labor Party. In a National Party seat, 8,162 electors will elect a member and in a Labor Party seat, 20,837 will elect a member.

Already it has been pointed out that the commissioners are required under the Act to keep State electoral boundaries as far as possible within the existing local government boundaries in a bid to retain community interest. Yet, under the present four-zonal arrangement and the way in which the maps have been drawn many Labor voters have been gathered into tight areas and no fewer than 12 local government boundaries have been truncated. There has been much mention lately of the small Aboriginal community of Wujal Wujal. I believe, Mr Acting Deputy President, that you mentioned that matter so I will not take the time of the Senate by going over the details of that redistribution. But I think it is worthwhile saying that because the Aboriginal population tended to vote for the Australian Labor Party and was, therefore a deep threat to the tenure of Mr Tenni, the National Party member, it has been cloistered into a landlocked island. This is simply because 66 per cent of those Aborigines voted Labor last time. In Queensland that is a crime to be punished whether one happens to be black or white.

The Senate must realise that Queensland is held hostage by a government that is vigorous in its discrimination and complete in its corruption. I have not used a number of adjectives that could be used because this is a public interest debate. Some people say that the Queensland Government is the best that can be put together by a complete gerrymander-I would not disagree with that statement-and it is only the gerrymander that keeps it together. When it comes to the gerrymander or, as Queensland has come to call it, the `Bjelkemander' the Queensland Premier makes past masters of this art of parliamentary burglary, such as Tom Playford and Henry Bolte, shine out like patron saints in comparison. To be frank to all fellow colleagues in this place, I believe the events in Queensland are such that its Government should be subject not only to a constitutional study or a committee of inquiry, but also to an inquiry on a much wider criminal scale by the National Crime Authority. It is committing a crime against the Queensland people.

On the tenth anniversary of the Whitlam dismissal, we were reminded of Albert Patrick Field, who was appointed to this place at the expense of the ALP nominee. Mr Acting Deputy President, that nominee was, Senator Malcolm Colston-yourself. It was an exercise cynically undertaken by Sir Johannes Bjelke-Petersen to help bring down the Whitlam Government. The so-called mandate this one-party government in Queensland professes to enjoy is based, in practice, on a 38 per cent vote, plus two political turncoats of whom honourable senators may have heard. Their names are Austin and Lane, former members of the Liberal Party. They switched from the Liberals to the Nationals in a highly cynical way, immediately after the last election, to give Sir Johannes Bjelke-Petersen the majority he needed to form a government in his own right without the taint of Liberal involvement. Where else in Australia is there a slush fund such as the Bjelke-Petersen Foundation, which through the Premier and sometimes his Cabinet colleagues, dispenses knighthoods, jobs for the boys, contracts and favours in repayment for donations or, should I say investments?

I intended to continue along that line but because of the nature of the debate I do not now intend to do so. But I think it is worthwhile saying at this stage that the Sun Herald of 10 November 1985, contained an article in the `On the Inside' column. It was headed: `Old, old story'. It stated:

Really! Following Joh's blatant boundary gerrymander, the Queensland Chief Electoral Commissioner John Andrews is set to be knighted in the New Year's Honours. And, he's been recommended for a Government plum job as chairman of the Queensland Sugar Board.

I do not need to say any more. I think most honourable senators will be able to judge for themselves why some of those things are now happening. The Queensland Government, in its latest move, has totally ditched its sugar industry. Through the gerrymander it has attempted to enshrine National Party control on a vote which is almost 10 per cent lower than that gained by any opposition party in the country. An example of the gerrymander is the way the proportion of votes and seats per zone has changed between the 1977 redistribution and the horror show proposed in 1985. In 1977, the south-east zone had 63.6 per cent of the voters and 57.3 per cent of the seats. In the 1985 plan the south-east zone has slightly more of the voters, 64.6 per cent, and the same number of seats, 57.3 per cent. Provincial cities in the zonal set-up in Queensland in 1977 had 17.1 per cent of the voters and 15.9 per cent of the seats. Under the new plan, the zone will have 16 per cent of the voters and 14.6 per cent of the seats.

It is also interesting when we come to the areas where the Bjelke-Petersen minority Government won 41 seats in 1983 with a percentage of only 38.9 per cent of the overall vote and formed a government following the defection of the two Liberals to help hold its power base together. In 1977 a 5 per cent proportion of votes was responsible for the destiny of 8.5 per cent of all seats in Queensland. Under the 1985 plan, 4.5 per cent of the votes will determine the outcome of 9 per cent of the seats. In the country zone in 1977 a total of 14.3 per cent of electors were represented by 18.3 per cent of the seats. The picture in 1985, when these proposals go ahead, will still be that 14.3 per cent of the voters will have 18.3 per cent of the seats. This will occur under the proposal which the commissioners have brought down.

In 1977, the average number of voters per seat in the four zones was 47 seats in the south-east zone with an average number of voters of 16,368 per seat; 13 seats in the provincial cities zone with an average of 15,952 voters per seat; seven seats in the western and far northern zone with an average of 8,586 voters per seat; and 15 seats in the country zone with an average of 11,515 voters per seat. Under the Bjelkemander proposal, in 1985 the south-east zone will have 51 seats with an average of 19,358 voters-the previous average was 16,368 so the figure is vastly up. The provincial cities zone will have 13 seats with an average of 18,756 voters-a figure which is vastly up again in terms of individual voters and seats. The western and far northern zone will have 8 seats with an average of merely 8,659-a figure which is marginally down. The country zone, with 17 seats, has two seats more than in 1977. It has an average of 13,314 voters per seat-a figure which is up but, in percentage terms, is nowhere near the extent of the increase in the more heavily populated areas on or near the eastern coast. In other words, the weighting effect of the zonal system has been aggravated by the 1985 proposed Bjelkemander compared with the already outrageous situation which was brought to bear in 1977. It is also worth while at this late stage mentioning just two of the points made by Sir Johannes Bjelke-Petersen in his second reading speech when he introduced the Bill into the Parliament. He said:

The four-zone system will continue the balanced representation, balanced development policy of my Government. Unlike the one vote, one value policy of other political parties, the zonal system ensures that there is an equal spread of new seats across the State. There will be four in southern Queensland and three in the central and north Queensland areas. This contrasts markedly with the Labor Party's Federal redistribution where, under its one vote, one value policy, all of the five seats were created in populous southern Queensland.
Further he said:

This is a very fair Bill, as it upholds the policy of balanced representation as opposed to one vote, one value, which would mean that at least an extra nine electorates would be created within 160 km of the Brisbane City Hall.

I think it is quite clear that there is no intention by the Premier in Queensland to introduce one vote, one value. He has weighted electorates in such a way that he has created a situation in which there are 20,000-odd voters in a provincial city electorate and 8,000 in a country seat such as Balonne.
Sitting suspended from 1.42 to 2 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Housing and Construction. I refer to the fact that one of the four major savings banks which provide in total over 50 per cent of the housing loans in Australia has announced that it intends to cut its housing loans by 70 per cent and that two other savings banks have indicated their intention to severely curtail lending for housing. Can the Minister say what alternative sources of funds are available to home buyers and at what interest rate?
—I am advised that the Treasurer made a statement this morning setting out alternative sources of finance. I will make sure that a copy of that statement is made available.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Did he see the report in the Adelaide Advertiser of 15 October entitled `Coalition bid to tax lotteries'? In that article Senator Messner, the Opposition's tax spokesman, was reported as having prepared suggestions on how the Government's capital gains tax proposal could be extended into other areas other than shares and property. The report suggested that secret plans by the Opposition involving the use of section 26AAA of the Income Tax Assessment Act to tax speculative windfall gains, such as lottery wins, at full marginal rates of taxation were being seriously considered.
—Order! The honourable senator is giving too much information in his question. I suggest that he bring his question to an end.

—Under that section such gains would be taxed without discounting for the effect of inflation. Will the Minister describe what impact such a move would have on things such as employment in that area and whether such proposals would vastly increase capital gains tax collections?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I cannot say that I actually saw the report in the Adelaide Advertiser to which Senator Foreman referred but I am not surprised that it was in the Adelaide Advertiser because I have a copy of a minute signed by Senator Messner as shadow Minister for finance and taxation and dated 7 October 1985. It is one of those copies of Opposition executive minutes which are thoughtfully leaked by members of the Opposition executive to the Australian Labor Party and the Press from time to time-indeed, almost on a daily basis these days. Such is the state of cohesion not just in the Liberal Party itself but in the coalition's shadow Ministry that confidential minutes are leaked almost on a daily basis. This minute, under the section headed, `Capital gains tax', refers to the sorts of things to which Senator Foreman referred. It says:

ANSWER.PARA: Under present tax arrangements, considerable speculative investment is subject to tax at marginal rates (e.g. short-term share, property, and futures investment). On equity grounds, `speculative' windfall gains such as lottery wins ought logically to have been included in any CGT.

The implication of that policy as enunciated by Senator Messner is, firstly, that a broadening of the section 26AAA provision would tax gains without making any allowance for inflation which, compared to the tax that the Government is proposing on capital gains, would be quite unfair. Senator Messner's reference to lottery wins opens up the whole question of an area of cash receipts presently not taxed in the hands of the receiver. It is indeed the thin edge of the wedge for a punters' tax. If a punter were to be taxed under section 26AAA there would be an average rate of tax on punters' winnings of about 36 per cent. If Senator Messner's policy were implemented we would find that every punter in Australia, every time he is lucky enough to have a win, would on average have 36 per cent of it seized straight away by Senator Messner.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask that the Minister table the statement from which he just quoted.
—It is your paper. You should be able to distribute copies of it yourself.
—The Minister has tabled the document.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Housing and Construction. Is it a fact that at this time last year a new home buyer would have faced a savings bank interest rate of 11.5 per cent and repayments of about $500 a month on a $50,000 loan? Is it also a fact that, due to the Hawke Government's high interest rate policies, the same potential borrower, unable to get the entire loan from a savings bank even at the much higher interest rate of 13.5 per cent, is now being forced to obtain a combined savings-trading bank loan at interest rates of up to 17.5 per cent, requiring repayments of more than $700 a month; that is, repayments some 40 per cent higher on the same loan than were necessary a year ago? In view of the fact that the Prime Minister has said that Australians will have to live with higher interest rates for a while, is there any relief in sight for home buyers hit by such a savage rise in repayments?

—In the financial year 1984-85 the number of loans by all significant lenders-that is, 323,370-rose by 2.8 per cent to a new annual record. In the three months to August 1985 total approvals by all lenders remained at a high level; that is, at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 336,000. The short term prospects report of the Indicative Planning Council forecast a reduction of 5 per cent in the 1985-86 total number of approvals by banks and permanent building societies. This would need downward revision if banks reduced further lending.
—I raise a point of order, Mr President. The Minister is simply not answering the question. I ask that the question be answered.
—There is no point of order.

—Thank you, Mr President. Perhaps Senator Chaney should instruct his back benchers about when points of order can properly be raised. While some privately owned banks have announced that they are reviewing their lending, the Commonwealth Savings Bank has indicated that it will be maintaining its lending target of $1.6 billion for the financial year. Borrowers who meet bank eligibility criteria should still be able to get housing loans from savings banks. The first home owners scheme continues to help low to moderate income earners into home ownership and, of course, the Government is monitoring the situation. The summary of the situation is that home ownership, particularly amongst low income families, has dramatically increased under the policies of the Hawke Government and will continue to do so.

—Order! I draw the attention of honourable senators to the length of questions that have been asked today. I suggest that far too much information is being given in the questions from both sides of the chamber. I ask that they seek information from Ministers, not provide it.

—Mr President, I have a point of order. I seek the guidance of the Chair. I would like to know whether it is in order for Senator Ryan to answer the question Senator Messner asked her two questions later when a quite different question was put to her by Senator Knowles. I ask you whether the Minister is under any obligation to answer questions in the order in which they are asked of her.
—Order! There is no point of order.

—I ask a question of the Minister representing the Minister for Communications. Does regional Australian Broadcasting Corporation radio in Queensland broadcast a racing service which is relayed from a Brisbane commercial radio station? Does the ABC have any concern that radio commercials are also sometimes relayed when the racing service is connected, as reported in the Sunday Sun of 10 November 1985? Was this consequence foreseen when the ABC made its disgraceful decision to discontinue its own racing service in Queensland? Does the ABC intend to request royalties for the numerous commercials which slip through?

—This question has a rather familiar ring about it. Senator Colston asked three questions. The answer to the first one is no; the ABC produces its own Saturday afternoon sporting program for regional areas of Queensland, which includes the ABC's own racing service. In answer to the second question, the Sunday Sun of 10 November was not specific--
—That's not right.

—Well, that is what I am advised by the Minister's office. The Sunday Sun of 10 November was not specific. The ABC takes a `clean feed'-I am not sure what that means; I am not familiar with the technical jargon or slang-of the course broadcaster and does not relay the commercial station's program. The answer to the third question-I have covered this point in answers to similar questions-is that the ABC at no time made a decision to discontinue its racing service in country Queensland. As an economy measure it changed its Brisbane sporting program format.

—By way of a supplementary question, Mr President, I ask: Did the Minister, in fact, say `no' in answer to the first question; that the racing service is relayed from a Brisbane commercial radio station?

—That is what I am advised by the Minister-that the answer to the first question is no; the ABC produces its own Saturday afternoon sporting program for regional areas of Queensland, which includes the ABC's own racing service.

—Is the Leader of the Government in the Senate aware of events in the Northern Territory Legislative Assembly yesterday in which the Leader of the Opposition in the Legislative Assembly said, in relation to an answer given by the Government, `Only those drongos could possibly make the link', which I suggest would not be considered an immoderate statement in this vicinity. Is it the case that at no time was Mr Collins given the opportunity to withdraw his remarks? Was Mr Collins then named and suspended from sittings for seven days? Does the Northern Territory Legislative Assembly, in fact, sit for only another seven days this year? Does the Minister see any connection between these events and the recent release of a report on the Chamberlain case which is due to be debated in the Northern Territory Legislative Assembly? Finally, in the light of these events, how does the Government feel the development of democracy is progressing in the Northern Territory?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Mason's question came in several parts. He asked whether I am aware of events in the Northern Territory Legislative Assembly yesterday. The answer to that part is no, but I must say that the statement quoted by Senator Mason has a certain air of veracity about it. I have known Mr Collins for a long time and he does have a precise, punctilious and exact way of expressing himself, and it seems to be an excellent description of the situation with which he was confronted. I was then asked whether Mr Collins was given the opportunity to withdraw his remarks. I do not know. I was asked whether the Assembly was, in fact, going to sit for only another seven days. I do not know. I was asked whether this was connected with the Chamberlain case. I do not know, but I assume so.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been asked to answer a question. I usually get objections when I answer them with this degree of precision, and I am getting them again. The last part of the question was whether I regarded--
—Senator Button, I suggest that the last part was about the only part of the question that came within your responsibilities.

—I made that quite clear, Mr President, in my answer. I was finally asked what I had to say about the progress of the development of democracy in the Northern Territory. I am eternally optimistic about that. I think that the most important thing, whether it is in Australia or outside Australia, is for systems of government to be, as it were, put on the stairway to life. I do not know how long it will take them to climb that stairway to a degree of enlightenment and sophistication such as we have attained in the Senate, but let me say that I think that in the case of the Northern Territory it will be a very long time. It will probably reach the point we are at in about the year 2000, and that will not be very far advanced.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Attorney-General. The Minister will be aware that the terms of office of members of the Commonwealth Legal Aid Council expired on 30 June 1985, the date from which the Council ceased to operate. Can the Minister inform the Senate what action is being taken to establish a new national legal aid advisory body?

—I am advised by the Attorney that at his direction the Department is developing a proposal as a matter of priority for the creation of an efficient and effective national legal aid monitoring and co-ordination mechanism, having regard to the contents of the final report of the departmental legal aid task force, which report was published in August this year. In general terms, the proposal at this stage is likely to involve the establishment of an identifiably separate part of the Department in conjunction with an appropriately constituted effective advisory body. The Attorney-General has indicated that he will consult interested persons, groups and bodies, including, of course, State legal aid commissions, on the detailed proposal when he has had an opportunity of considering it.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Housing and Construction. It follows that and is indeed the question asked by Senator Knowles to which no answer has been given. I point out to the Minister that the question relates to the cost of home loans and not to the number of home loans. Is it a fact that this time last year a new home buyer would have faced a savings bank interest rate of 11.5 per cent and repayments of about $500 a month on a $50,000 loan? Is it also a fact that, under this Government's high interest rate policies, that same potential borrower is having to obtain a combined savings-trading bank loan at interest rates of up to 17.5 per cent, with repayments of more than $700 a month; that is, 40 per cent higher than the same sized loan required a year ago? I ask the Minister: In view of the fact that the Prime Minister has said that Australians will have to live with high interest rates for a while-I use his words-is there any relief in sight for home buyers hit by such a savage rise in repayments?

—I do not intend to confirm or deny the results of Senator Chaney's arithmetic. I simply remind Senator Chaney and all honourable senators that the growth in home ownership, particularly by low income earners, under this Government has been dramatic. There are now hundreds of thousands of people in possession of homes who were not a few years ago. As to the details of the Government's current response, I refer Senator Chaney to the Treasurer's statement of this morning.
