—I will answer Senator Vigor now. I have not seen the questions, but even if I had, I could not give an absolute guarantee that they would all be answered. Some of them may well be not answerable because the information is just not available, for example. But I will give a guarantee that they will be submitted to the Minister for Communications (Mr Duffy) and that I will endeavour to get answers in the time that has been specified. If it is not possible to do so in that time, I will endeavour to get them as soon as possible.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vigor Sen D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister. I will present these questions to the Minister at the next possible time. I seek leave to have the questions incorporated in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The questions read as follows-
TELECOM: COLONIAL MENTALITY ON TECHNOLOGY
On 10 September (Hansard page 85) Estimates Committee C was told by Telecom's representative:

``Our research and development efforts are basically an attempt to have an understanding of the current technologies, run trials and make an assessment of their suitability for application in our network. An important part of that is to decide when the technology is mature enough for it to be prudent for us to commit ourselves to investment in the network''.

This is most unsatisfactory when Telecom's buying muscle and Australian research and development skills could enable an export-capable Australian industry to be established in the telecommunications area. Will the government consider making it a statutory obligation upon Telecom to foster research and development in Australia and to encourage the development rather than the modification of communications technology here?
AUSTRALIA POST CONTRACTUAL ARRANGEMENTS

Only 69% of Express Courier articles were delivered on time in Western Australia, while in Victoria the success rate was 75%. I understand that a good part of the problem lies in airline uplift arrangements at Tullamarine and Adelaide. In answer to a question I asked on Tuesday, 10th September at the Senate Estimates Committee C, I was told that the airlines are required to uplift, on flights specified by Australia Post, all airmail tendered to them.
Are there any remedies in Australia Post's contractual arrangements with the airlines that cover noncompliance on the part of the airline?

If so, why has the management done nothing about the 31% and 25% respective late delivery figures for Express Courier deliveries in Western Australia and Victoria? Surely no private enterprise would allow that situation to continue if competitors were getting an advantage in a tight market, as is the case with competition between Australia Post and private courier services?

If there are no penalties for noncompliance, when do the contractual arrangements end, and what encouragement will the government give the negotiators to ensure that the airlines cannot walk away untouched, from failures to deliver as contracted?
Will the Government, in the mean time, legislate to permit Qantas to carry mail throughout the country, thereby adding further incentive for the domestic airlines to honour their agreements?
AUSTRALIA POST: INDUSTRIAL DISPUTATION

We have just seen a major dispute that arose when New South Wales management tried to gear work practices to peaks of mail throughout. In response to a question by Senator Parer, Estimates Committee C discovered that last financial year it cost 11 million dollars in additional overtime to clear New South Wales mail backlogs caused by industrial problems.

I have had Question on Notice No. 113 on the Notice Paper since 19 March, dealing with how disputes arise, and what sort of planning has gone into the establishment of new mail centres. There is no indication that an answer is anywhere in the offing. I am happy to modify the question if a particular part has created compilation problems in answering. I would like to get an answer. I am sure that honourable Senators and the general public would very much like to know what management is doing to settle matters before they develop into disputes. It is in Australia Post's interests to release this information to the public. I hope that the interest of the Minister for Communications will help get this information into the open so that the mail situation in New South Wales can be properly assessed.
PUBLIC BROADCASTING

I make two points: (1) Funding levels kept the same despite more stations and especially greater levels of aboriginal broadcasting; (2) From the written evidence, there was a tug-of-war between the Departments of Aboriginal Affairs and Communications over who should control the funds for aboriginal broadcasting.

At page 861 of the Estimates Hansard of Friday, 20 September, we were told that the Explanatory Notes do not reflect the arrangements involving the Public Broadcasting Foundation. This was, and I quote, because the Explanatory Notes ``were prepared before certain Government decisions were taken''.

That, I understand, is bureaucratic language to indicate that the Minister for Communications successfully restored the funding to the Public Broadcasting Foundation on the eve of the budget speech. I applaud the Minister's determination. It would have been better still if he'd been able to get an increase in funding to take account of the additional aboriginal broadcasting to occur this year. In fact, the whole of the public broadcasting network of some 60 stations around the country costs around 7 million dollars to run. That's what it costs for the running of the EA stations in Melbourne and Sydney. The Government provides about 1.3 million dollars to the public broadcasting sector, with more than half of that going to cover part of the costs of ethnic broadcasting groups which buy station time.
The public broadcasting sector in turn provides training skills for thousands of people. It has in many ways taken over from the ABC in giving training to new people.

I believe that the government would give long-term sustenance to the public broadcasting sector by making a one-off endowment. That would enable the Public Broadcasting Foundation to make appropriate investments, so that recurrent funding wasn't a major problem. There will alwyas be a lot of frantic fund-raising. Budgets will generally operate on a shoestring. But at least with an endowment, we wouldn't find any future government taking political action against the public broadcasters by withdrawing funds.

I note, in the response to a question I put on notice, that the Treasurer has arranged to consider sales tax exemption on capital equipment purchases. This move, would certainly assist communities involved in public broadcasting. They certainly provide the training that leads people to employment in the media. They also provide an excellent outlet for self-expression in various forms. The Australian music industry has certainly been given a major fillip with the growth of public broadcasting. Groups that have always found the conservative approach of the commercial broadcasters insurmountable, have found an audience on public radio. Some of them have then gone on to major commercial success also.

On behalf of public broadcasters and participants around the country, I ask the Minister whether there is additional information available on Government attitudes towards a one-off endowment and sales-tax exemption for public broadcasters and public television.
FORWARD DEVELOPMENT UNIT
The Forward Development Unit has been given substantial new staff resources.

When it was established in February, its terms of reference were to deal with the medium and long-term future for commercial television-and to look closely at opportunities brought by advanced delivery technology.

At the end of April, the Minister reaffirmed that equalisation was a long-term objective. Yet the report of the Forward Development Unit dealt only with the short-term, and was quite nebulous about how many longer-term rearrangements might occur. Did the Minister for Communications modify in writing the terms of reference, or did the Unit reinterpret the terms of reference in the light of policy announcements made in May? Is this a case of ``Yes, Minister''?

In the light of strong statements in favour of giving the supplementary licence scheme a fair trial-these have come from within the ACTU and public interest groups-can the Minister say whether any part of the supplementary licence approach will be retained?

And if so, what will be done to get the Department to process material more quickly? Only 4 of the original 98 applications have gone to the Tribunal, and the television one in Canberra has been put under pressure by both commercial interests and the Minister.
LICENCES FOR NEW STATIONS

According to page 436 of the Estimates Hansard, there are currently 835 Expressions of Interest (not all compatible) from people hoping to obtain a broadcasting licence awaiting processing by the Department of Communications. In addition, the Department is currently assesssing 128 firm proposals for broadcasting licences, plus more for supplementary licences. Clearance of television stations from Band II will take up additional Department of Communications resources. Only about half the planning resources will be available for broadcast station planning, and consequently they expect to process only between 15 and 20 of the proposals before them this year.
The Department of Communications is being given additional resources, but not the Broadcasting Tribunal. The Tribunal gets very little advance notice of licence applications.

The Annual Report of the Department of Communications indicates that low-power community stations are being planned for the Melbourne metroplitan area. But in answer to my question on notice No. 193 in Hansard of March 29th 1985, the Department could not predict how many new public stations might be licensed over the next three years.
Will the government be setting priority areas for the Station Planning Branch to tackle, or will we continue the very slow progress of the previous years on a large number of fronts?

In a letter dated the 28 October, the Minister for Communications has indicated to me that he is aware of the planning delays, and that he has asked his department to examine ways in which some of those delays may be overcome. Has the Minister given the Department a deadline by which it is to report on these matters? Can the Minister tell me now how the Department plans to overcome those delays?
LICENCE FEE COLLECTION

Last year the High Court ruled that the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal could not ask for extra financial documents where it wasn't satisfied that figures presented as a station's gross earnings, were actually a fair reflection of what was going on. Has the government examined simplifying the process by basing licence fees purely on advertising revenue?
If so, when can such a change be anticipated?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —During the hearings of Senates Estimates Committee C, I asked some questions about the racing service that was provided by the Australian Broadcasting Corporation in Queensland. The background to what I am about to say and the question I asked at that time is that the racing broadcasting service in Queensland, despite what the Australian Broadcasting Corporation says, has been discontinued. A skeleton service of some sort is provided for people in regional areas. In fact, whenever I ask questions about this matter the people in the Australian Broadcasting Corporation seem to get very twitchy and defensive about a decision which was made and was not in the interests of the Queensland people.

SPEECH.PARA: I should mention that I asked a question at Question Time in the Senate this afternoon and again the information which had been provided to the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh)-I do not blame the Minister in any way-was a little too smart by half. The question was not answered. I do not have the question with me as it was my intention to raise the matter during the adjournment debate tonight. I probably will use that opportunity rather than raise it at this stage. One of the questions I asked during the hearings of the Senate Estimates Committee was:
I would also like to know what sort of savings were involved in taking this service off and whether the administration in Queensland looked at any other area where it could make similar savings.
The service to which I was referring was the broadcast of races in Queensland and taking off the service altogether in the Brisbane metropolitan area. The answer I got was:
The changed arrangements for the Queensland Racing Service are estimated to save $11,642 in 1985-86 and $31,892 in a full year.

The answer went on, but it is not relevant to what I want to say. I ask that the Australian Broadcasting Corporation give full details of how it estimates that saving of $11,642. I cannot and do not expect the answer now but I do expect that the Australian Broadcasting Corporation will provide that type of information through the Minister. I believe that the changes which were made in Queensland resulted in extra costs rather than savings. I want to indicate why I think some of this may be so.

I have calculated the possible extra costs that might be pertinent at the moment. There could be wages for an additional radio announcer each Saturday afternoon, the additional radio announcer being required because of the need to have somebody take the place of the person who normally runs the racing service and as well as that having someone there to cross over to racing broadcasts which are given out by 4BC. Including penalty rates, I have calculated that this person would cost about $110 for a Saturday afternoon. There is a person who gives a racing preview each Saturday morning. I am not sure of the costs that would be involved there but those were normally given by the person who did the racing broadcast previously, Larry Pratt, and I would estimate these would be not less than $50 for that morning.

I understand that an extra studio is being used. Studios are normally hired out by the Australian Broadcasting Corporation at $10 an hour; so there is approximately six hours extra maintenance of the studio, which would cost about $60. There are costs associated with the use of a sporting assistant. This sporting assistant was previously employed elsewhere ferrying results between the two studios. My estimated costs are about $90. There is also the additional cost of two days salary to replace Monday and Tuesday programs which were previously serviced by the racing commentator. My estimated cost there is about $180. That brings to about $490 all those extra costs that would have to be incurred because of the fact that the racing broadcasting service has been discontinued. I think that we should perhaps add the weekly cost of Seventel which has now been introduced into the Australian Broadcasting Corporation in Brisbane so that the racing odds and results are available. Seventel is used on a Saturday afternoon only. I do not know the cost of that but perhaps that should be added as well.

The savings that have been obtained because of the fact that the radio racing broadcasts went off the air are about 60 per cent of the salary paid to the former racing commentator, which approximates about $317 a week. It seems to me that the Australian Broadcasting Corporation is saving about $317 a week. It has extra costs of about $490 a week and, if my calculations are correct, that is about $170 extra costs that it is incurring. Therefore, I would like to look at this alleged saving of $11,642 very carefully. I have some doubts whether that figure is correct. I ask the Minister to ask his colleague in the other place to obtain from the Australian Broadcasting Corporation a detailed breakdown of how the Queensland racing service is estimated to save this $11,642, especially in the light of any additional costs that have been incurred, with a detailed breakdown of those additional costs because of the fact that the racing broadcasting service is no longer available in the metropolitan area and the service obtained from 4BC is available only to regional areas in Queensland.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The vote for the Department of Communications includes a vote for payments to the Australian Broadcasting Corporation. There are many matters which ought to have the attention of this Parliament in relation to the Australian Broadcasting Corporation. The first matter I intend to raise is a report from the Ombudsman on the case involving Mr Cotton. This is a significant report, significant for this reason if for no other, and I quote from the report:

SPEECH.PARA: This is the first report I have found it necessary to make to the Parliament.

The Ombudsman usually discharges his responsibilities by some form of conciliation between departments or statutory authorities where he is investigating a matter and the person who has been aggrieved or whose rights have been infringed upon. Only when he finds that the authority or department has acted in a fashion where it is not prepared to take notice of the Ombudsman's recommendations or has failed to co-operate with the Ombudsman, does he seek to report to Parliament. The office of Ombudsman has been in existence for many years. This is the first occasion the Ombudsman has had to come to the Parliament with a report. I quote from paragraph 10 of his report:

The fact that the Parliament is now only receiving a report about a complaint made in April 1981 will be explained by the events and actions which I will recount. In short, however, the ABC baulked my investigation at almost every turn in an exercise of obfuscation and prevarication without parallel in my eight years experience as the first Commonwealth Ombudsman.
In relation to a videotape that he wanted to see, at paragraph 13 the Ombudsman says:
The video tape was displayed to us after repeated correspondence and telephone calls-a story in itself.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is Professor Richardson, is it?
—This is Professor Jack Richardson, the Commonwealth Ombudsman.
—The most experienced Ombudsman?

—As Senator Peter Rae says, he is not only a most experienced judicial and administrative officer but in fact the most senior person to hold that position throughout the Commonwealth of Australia. At paragraph 16 he says:

SPEECH.PARA: The attitude of the ABC from the beginning prevented me from dealing with the complaints according to the normal investigational processes of my office under the Ombudsman Act 1976.
At paragraph 20 he says:

The ABC failed to produce the documents as required, that failure in my opinion, amounting to a contravention of section 36 of the Ombudsman Act which makes it an offence for a person refusing or failing, without reasonable excuse, to furnish information which I have required in pursuance to the Ombudsman Act.

TALK.START.PARA: —What sanctions are there under that Act?

—Senator Peter Baume draws my attention to whether there are sanctions available under the Act. The most significant sanction under the Act or, indeed, the most significant sanction available to the Parliament would be not to give the ABC its appropriation, which I think would be a fairly commendable thing until we get some intelligent replies to this report. At paragraph 42 of the report are the Ombudsman's conclusions, where at conclusion number (ii) he says:

SPEECH.PARA: The actions of the ABC in handling the Principal's complaint
That is the complaint of Mr Cotton--
within its own organisation were unreasonable and unjust because it failed to deal with matters of substance and accepted as facts matters which were not substantiated.
The report concludes in paragraph 66:

The self-serving attitude of the ABC in this case revealed by my investigation and its determination to resist the Ombudsman will I hope dramatically demonstrate to Senators and Members of the Parliament the need for an effective mechanism of external accountability to protect individual members of the community against unfair and unjust treatment by this publicly funded agency. It is simply unacceptable that this government instrumentality, under the guise of independence, or some other assertion, should be allowed to function as a Caesar's palace-
I presume by that he means Caesar as in the Caesars of ancient Rome and not Caesar as in the Nevada gambling house, although one wonders from time to time-
when legitimate complaints are made about it, as in the case I investigated.

If there is one thing that the whole of the Ombudsman's report demonstrates, it is that the ABC has clearly regarded itself, in this particular instance, as being in some way above the law. In particular, it has regarded itself as being able, authorised and somehow proper in its behaviour to resist the Commonwealth Ombudsman undertaking investgations. The Ombudsman complains to this Parliament under section 17 of the Ombudsman Act 1976, virtually for the first time in a decade, and describes the obfuscation and prevarication of the ABC. He describes the self-serving attitude of the ABC. He describes the ABC resisting providing him with information. He describes the ABC as unjust and unreasonable. He says the ABC has failed to produce documents. He says that the ABC:
. . . prevented me from dealing with the complaints according with the normal investigational processes-

There has not been a satisfactory explanation, not so much of the intricacies or the validities of Mr Cotton's case but of the way in which the Corporation has responded to the complaints made by the Commonwealth Ombudsman.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are two issues.

—As Senator Peter Rae says, the issues are quite separate. In terms of the appropriation debate, I am not concerned with the question of the validity or otherwise of Mr Cotton's complaint. That has been determined. It is certainly true that the Ombudsman found that he was unjustly and unreasonably dealt with, but that is a separate matter. What is of significance is that this Parliament funds two offices. It funds the ABC and it funds the Commonwealth Ombudsman. One of the reason it funds the Commonwealth Ombudsman is that that institution, that statutory office, has a series of responsibilities. Basically, those responsibilities are to discharge a conciliatory functions between a complainant and a department, a complainant and a statutory authority, or whatever it happens to be. In virtually every single case- although I have not been through all the Ombudsman's reports for the last 10 years-the Ombudsman has been able to conclude his investigations without coming to the Parliament. He comes to the Parliament once in a decade. He has come to the Parliament in the course of this financial year to report on an investigation involving the ABC.

SPEECH.PARA: What we have not had from the ABC is not a proper explanation about Mr Cotton's case but a proper explanation about why it put in the way of the Commonwealth Ombudsman difficulties, obstructions and prevarications. Indeed, it refused to respond to the requests that the Ombudsman made initially to see a video which he had to look at in order to determine whether Mr Cotton had a case or did not have a case. We do not know whether documents were properly provided.

I do not believe that until such time as there is a satisfactory explanation from the ABC the Parliament should vote to give money to the ABC. Until such time as it is satisfied that the ABC has properly responded to the complaints made by the Commonwealth Ombudsman, I believe the appropriations for the Department of Communications ought to be delayed. Certainly, I believe that should be delayed until the Senate resumes in 10 days time. That will give the ABC plenty of opportunity to respond. In 10 days time the Senate can determine whether it is satisfied with the explanation it has received. I believe that is one of the issues concerning the Department of Communications, one of the issues arising in terms of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation, which needs some exposure, indeed some investigation.

TALK.START.PARA: —When the matter was raised in the Estimates Committee what kind of response did you receive from the Corporation?

—In answer to Senator Peter Baume's question, we received responses which I think would be described as unsatisfactory, at the very least. The other matter to be raised concerns the ABC program, the National. If ever there has been a situation in which public money has been expended on attempting to change the character and nature of the Commission, now the Corporation, in terms of the role it plays in the delivery of news services to the people of Australia, the National must go down as constituting one of the most monumental failures that has ever been undertaken. The fact that it has failed I think is not something simply to be held against the ABC. In any broadcasting situation new formats and new programs will be tried. Inevitably, in anything which relies on a market a fair number of those new things will fail, whether they be television mini-series, the presentation of news reports, changes of programming, or whatever. That degree of failure is inevitable.

SPEECH.PARA: The question is whether the failure was occasioned not because the National was not a good program but for two other reasons. Firstly, did the National fail because the ABC was trying to do something which it should not have done? That is to say, was it trying to enter into a degree of competition with the commercial broadcasters, which does not constitute a proper part of its charter? Secondly, did the National fail because it has been internally sabotaged by politics within the ABC? I refer in particular to the degree of hostility from certain other persons in the ABC, particularly within the program affectionately known around this place as Car-Wash, that is to say, the Carleton-Walsh Report. Has public money been poured down the drain as a result of the sabotage of one news program in order to expand the operations of the Carleton-Walsh Report in an attempt to make it a five nights a week operation-in fact, to make it the centrepiece, as it were, of the ABC's news and public affairs broadcasting? I think we will have an opportunity in the course of the debate on appropriations for the Department of Communications to raise this matter and to look at some of the internal memoranda concerning the way in which the National has been analysed in reports written by other people within the ABC. Again, when we resume in a week or so, I hope the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) will be able to provide some answers about that.

Thirdly, I wish to express a degree of dissatisfaction-given the shortage of time I will do it quickly-with the way in which the ABC discharges its responsibilities for the broadcasting and coverage of science in Australia. There is no doubt that the ABC's Science Show is probably the best program the ABC broadcasts. I think the Science Show together with the Health Report, the Technology Report and the series that used to be known as Warm Boot, and various other programs on the ABC, have done a great deal to advance the public understanding of scientific issues in the Australian community. However, the general approach of the ABC to the reporting of scientific issues and issues of concern arising in the field of science, within the framework of their wider responsibilities in terms of news and coverage of news programs, I think for a national broadcaster has been lamentable.

My next point, which will have to wait until some later time, concerns ABC orchestras and why it is that for the maintenance of six ABC orchestras we expend more money than we expend on the whole of the Australia Council's vote. Why is it that the Australia Council is kept short of money to spread over all the art forms while for the maintenance of six orchestras the ABC gets more money per annum than the whole of the arts community gets through the Australia Council in any financial year?

TALK.START.PARA: —And is sitting on and virtually not using nearly $5m worth of land for that purpose as well. That is not taken into account either.
—Senator Peter Rae rightly observes that the ABC has unused properties. In view of the time, that is an issue to which I will return.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Malaysian Student: Mr Ahmad Othman-Australian Broadcasting Corporation: Racing Service in Queensland-Northern Territory-Death of Bishop O'Loughlin-Steel Industry

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Pursuant to sessional order, I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 6 November an article entitled `Ousted student finds support' appeared in the higher education supplement of the Australian newspaper. It concerned a Malaysian student, Mr Ahmad Othman, who was expelled from this country. The story raises very serious concerns. Either someone in the office of the Minister for Education (Senator Ryan) has lied about the matter or there is a form of student assessment going on within the Government that is entirely new. The article states, in part:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . claims by officials that he had failed to make satisfactory academic progress and had not paid the overseas student charge in 1984 and 1985.
I do not wish to contest the claim that this man had not paid the overseas student charge. His explusion could have been quite properly made on that basis. The article goes on to say:
A spokesman for Senator Ryan's office in Canberra said that Mr Othman had shown poor academic performance and had failed to pay his fees for the past two years.
It then purports to quote the spokesman as follows:
`He had failed a number of times and the decision to terminate Mr Othman's visa was taken on his poor academic progress,' he said yesterday.

If the Government wishes to expel someone for not having paid his student charge, let it do so; but for an official in Senator Ryan's office to hide behind the excuse that the student in question had failed, as least in part, to satisfy an academic record and that this had been the cause of his explusion is reasonable only if it is correct. I have before me a letter from the Faculty of Economics Studies at the University of New England, Armidale, New South Wales, dated 7 November, the day after this newspaper story appeared, signed by John Phillips, Dean of the Faculty. The letter, to the editor of the higher education section of the Australian, reads:

Your report on the expulsion of the Malaysian student, Mr Ahmad Othman, who enrolled in this Faculty, raises serious questions of bureaucratic interference in the academic affairs of universities and of discrimination against overseas students.

Let me state quite plainly the Mr Othman, who first enrolled here in 1983, was and still is a student in good standing in this faculty. His academic progress has not resulted in his exclusion from further enrolment in the Faculty, and I must express my concern at the statement from Senator Ryan's office that the decision to terminate his visa was based on his poor academic performance.

The letter goes on to expand on that point. This is a very serious matter. Either someone in Senator Ryan's office has made a genuine error of fact, in which case I expect Senator Ryan to acknowledge this publicly as quickly as she is able, or someone in Senator Ryan's office has deliberately misstated the facts about Mr Othman in order to hide the fact that he was expelled from this country for failing to pay his student charge. It is now over to Senator Ryan to clear this up. The student obviously was in good academic standing and it is not correct-it is in fact a gross slander upon the student-to claim in any way that his expulsion from this country was occasioned by his poor academic progress, as claimed from within Senator Ryan's office.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —This afternoon in Question Time I asked a question about the racing service provided by the Australian Broadcasting Corporation in Queensland. I must say that I was dissatisfied with the answer but I in no way reflect upon the Minister who answered the question, Senator Walsh. I do, however, reflect upon the advisers who provided the information for the Minister. I provided the Minister with the question beforehand, which gave the Minister and the Department of Communications the opportunity to obtain the answer before Question Time. It seems to me that someone in the Department or in the Australian Broadcasting Corporation itself is doing his best to snow anybody who asks questions about the Australian Broadcasting Corporation's radio racing service in Queensland.

SPEECH.PARA: The plain fact is that the Australian Broadcasting Corporation in Brisbane terminated the contract of Larry Pratt, who used to broadcast races from the various racing locations in Brisbane. Those broadcasts were sent out over the airwaves of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation not only to the metropolitan area but also to all regional areas of Queensland. For some reason, which I have not yet been able to determine-I have been given some reasons but I do not believe them-the Australian Broadcasting Corporation in Queensland decided to terminate Larry Pratt's contract in relation to radio. I understand that he still does some television work for the Corporation. Since then the ABC in Queensland has not really had a racing service as such. I suppose that if one wanted to be pedantic one could say that it does have a racing service because it takes the broadcasts of the races around Brisbane from station 4BC and relays these to areas outside Brisbane. Within Brisbane there is no broadcast of the races themselves. I suppose one could say that the ABC does have a racing service because it provides a few tips in the morning and some results during the afternoon service, but it is not really a racing service as such. To be a proper racing service it would have to have its own broadcaster at the races. This afternoon I asked the following question:
Does regional Australian Broadcasting Corporation radio in Queensland broadcast a racing service which is relayed from a Brisbane commercial radio station?

The answer was no. That so astounded me that in Question Time this afternoon I asked one of the very few supplementary questions that I have asked in this place, just to make sure that I had heard correctly. The answer was:
. . . No, the ABC produces its own Saturday afternoon sporting program for regional areas of Queensland, which includes the ABC's own racing service.

Again, I am not reflecting on the Minister; I am reflecting on the person who provided the information for the Minister. I am not quite sure whether that person was trying to be too smart by half by saying that the sporting program includes the ABC's own racing service. It does not really; it includes a service which is provided by station 4BC. I asked:
Does the ABC have any concern that radio commercials are also sometimes relayed when the racing service is connected.
I referred to a report in the Sunday Sun of 10 November 1985. The answer I got was this:
The Sunday Sun of the 10 November was not specific. The ABC takes a `clean feed' . . . of the course broadcaster and does not relay the commercial station's program.

I tried to obtain some information about that this afternoon but, because it is fairly difficult to obtain that sort of information within a couple of hours, the information that I have is probably not comprehensive. However, I intend to follow the matter up tomorrow, and probably over the weekend, to find out what this clean feed is and whether a clean feed actually occurs. The information I was given this afternoon was that there could be an assumption that a clean feed was made, but it is impossible to have a clean feed. Exactly what that means I am not sure, but I will follow it up over the weekend. The information that was given to me this afternoon was that the ABC is channelling in on the 4BC program, which means that commercials will come over if there is a delay. It was implied in the answer this afternoon that the commercials do not come over the ABC because of this `clean feed', but information given to me this afternoon was that the commercials do come over when there is a delay. This afternoon I referred to the Sunday Sun of 10 November. I now refer to the Sunday-Mail. It is an indication that I did not read the Sunday-Mail very carefully last Sunday that I did not see, until this afternoon, this comment by Greg Atherton, who is a racing journalist for the Sunday-Mail, regarding country races:
Complaints continue unabated from country areas regarding the totally inadequate racing service being received through the ABC since the sacking of race-caller Larry Pratt.

Most object to the impersonal service being doled out by Aunty. But no real blame can be laid with the studio man at the ABC. After all, he depends on whatever 4BC provides as he has no direct link with the caller at the track to ask for information. However, every cloud has a silver lining. A number of commercials are sneaking over the ABC air waves, to the joy of the advertisers.

All I want to indicate this evening is that I am not satisfied with the answers that were given. However, I stress again that I do not put any blame at the foot of the Minister. I think honourable senators would understand what I mean by that. The Minister is given information from the Department through the Minister in the other place. What I am saying is that there are some people in the Department or in the Australian Broadcasting Corporation itself who are upset that questions are being asked about what is really a serious situation for many people in rural areas in Queensland. It is a serious situation for many people who are just outside the range of regional transmitters in some northern and southern parts of Brisbane who cannot pick up 4BC and cannot get anything over the ABC. It is a serious situation.

What I intend to do is to find out, over the weekend, more about the actual questions that I asked. If it seems that people in the Department of Communications or the ABC are deliberately trying to snow a senator in this place I shall raise the matter again. For those people in Communications and the Australian Broadcasting Corporation who will obviously read the Hansard record of what I have had to say, I warn them that just because they have made a wrong decision in Queensland on some very dubious grounds they should not try to hide the facts of what is happening. I am a fairly persistent character and if I think that somebody is not providing me with the information I will keep digging until I am able to obtain it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kilgariff Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate must have been concerned to hear the matter that Senator Peter Baume raised in the Senate in the adjournment debate tonight regarding Mr Othman and the fact that he has been removed from Australia. Mr Othman was a student at a university. It has been said that he was removed because of his poor record. This has now been refuted by Senator Peter Baume. As a member of the Opposition's immigration and ethnic affairs committee, I am particularly concerned about this matter. I believe the Government and the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hurford) must look at the situation as a matter of urgency. If Mr Othman has been removed from the country on improper grounds, ill-proved grounds, I believe the Government should take immediate steps to rectify the matter. We look to the Government to carry out a very earnest investigation of the situation immediately.

SPEECH.PARA: Tonight I rise to speak again, to set the record straight, on the Northern Territory Government's record on the development and financial management of the Territory. Honourable senators may remember that a few days ago I endeavoured to have incorporated in the Senate Hansard a report regarding the Northern Territory Government's commitments to tourist development projects. It was actually a financial statement on the matters that have been criticised, but I have referred to those before. I was not permitted to have the report included in Hansard. Since the election of the first Hawke Government in 1983 the Northern Territory has had nothing from the Federal Government but criticism, scepticism and a negative attitude to any positive initiative the Territory might take. The Minister for Finance, Senator Walsh, has continued his attack in this chamber on what he claims is a lack of fiscal responsibility in the Territory. I believe he should look at his own Government's record on responsibility to the Territory, because it has shown very little. It has reneged on agreements reached between its Ministers and the Northern Territory Government, such as the agreement reached over superannuation.

The Government has bailed out of its commitments in the Territory, such as the one it gave to build the new Darwin Airport. Having spent about $20m it decided it would pull out, leaving contractors stranded and the Northern Territory with an airport little better, and in fact much worse, than some in Third World countries. Some of its commitments to the Territory it did not even attempt to meet; for example, the Alice Springs to Darwin railway. It shelved this project after setting up an inquiry into the economic feasibility of the project, which I believe knew what it intended to find before it even commenced its hearings. The problems which have been associated with getting hold of the Hill inquiry's reasoning on its decision, under freedom of information legislation, bear witness to the reluctance of the Federal Government to come clean and publicly explain how it came to its conclusions.

What we do know is that the Government completely ignored the defence implications of the railway, which have been stated by leading authorities from the Australian National University's Strategic and Defence Studies Unit to be of great importance. The Northern Territory Government has since engaged private, and impartial, consultants to examine the feasibility of the railway and they have reached the conclusion that it can be a profitable venture. The Hon. Ian Tuxworth, the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory, announced last week at the Northern Australian Development Conference that construction of the line would commence in 1987. The Territory has tired of waiting for the Commonwealth to come to the party and do the right thing by northern Australians and, in fact, Australia. The line will be built by the Territory with private finance; that is, finance obtained around Australia. It will run at a profit, which is something that no other line in Australia, including Mr Hill's New South Wales railway, has been able to do.

I know that there will be some scepticism from the Federal Government on this proposal, not least of which will come from Senator Walsh. But I would just like to hark back to Senator Walsh's comments earlier this year concerning the natural gas pipeline from central Australia to Darwin. I recall Senator Walsh standing over there and telling the Senate that the whole concept was `pie in the sky'. It may interest Senator Walsh, who is now in the chamber, to know that that pie in the sky is now being laid at the rate of three metres a minute, which runs into many kilometres a day, and the Territory is doing it on its own. The Commonwealth is not paying for it. It is being privately funded because private enterprise, at least, has faith in the Territory. I believe the pipeline is costing some $380m and is one of the largest lease arrangements of its kind.

Given Senator Walsh's views on the prospects of the pipeline, I do not think that we can put too much store by the Federal Government's appraisal of the Territory's ventures in the Territory. I certainly will not be putting any faith in whatever views Senator Walsh may express on the proposed railway. Senator Walsh has consistently put a very slanted view on the management of the Territory economy by the Northern Territory Government. I would like again to set the record straight on our tourist development projects. As leave to have the statement incorporated in Hansard was refused earlier, I will not attempt to do so again tonight. In this free world and free country, I would have thought that the report that I have endeavoured to have included in the Senate Hansard would have at least been permitted to be included.

While I have spent some time tonight dwelling on Senator Walsh's attitude to the self-help that has been shown in the Northern Territory, I wish to say a few words about a member of the Northern Territory community who is far more deserving of the Senate's attention. I refer to the late Bishop O'Loughlin of Darwin, who passed away today. I was deeply sorry to hear of his passing, as he was a most revered man in the Northern Territory. He was 74 years of age and would have been Bishop of Darwin for 37 years next January. He was born on 25 July 1911 at Brompton in Adelaide and was educated at the Christian Brothers College. In 1930 he entered the Order of Missionaries of the Sacred Heart, and was ordained as a priest in 1935. Between 1937 and 1938 he held a position as a prefect of studies at Downlands College in Toowoomba, Queensland. Between 1947 and 1948 he was Director of Catholic Education in Rabaul. On 13 January 1949 he was appointed Bishop of Darwin, and was consecrated as Bishop at St Francis Xavier Cathedral, in Adelaide. He was one of the youngest bishops to be appointed in Australia, being only 38 years of age at that time. In 1974 he celebrated his twenty-fifth anniversary of his appointment.

Bishop O'Loughlin worked unstintingly and often under considerable pressure for the benefit of his flock in the Territory and had particular interest in the welfare of those on the Catholic missions, the Catholic education system and his far flung parishioners in the Northern Territory. Recognition of his work was made in the award of the Companion of St Michael and St George for distinguished service to the church and the Aboriginal people. He was also recently awarded a Rotary award-the Paul Harris Fellowship for community service. His ill-health and his death today is no doubt as a result of his complete dedication to the Northern Territory, and while the Territory will mourn his passing he will be remembered for his influence and work carried out for the betterment of all in the Northern Territory. Indeed, he was a great Australian. I understand that he will be accorded a state funeral tomorrow week-that is, 22 November-in Darwin.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise briefly an important matter affecting the Illawarra region in that it is, of course, a major steel producer at the Port Kembla steelworks. This emerges from some comments made in an interesting contribution by Senator Puplick in a discussion of the Steel Industry Authority report. It seemed appropriate that, Senator Puplick having raised very properly some sound points on that report, some other matters affecting the steel industry and their impact on the region-and, of course, on the whole of Australia-should be raised briefly tonight.

SPEECH.PARA: In the first place I draw to the attention of the Senate the balance of payments implications of the contribution made by the steel industry to exports last year, which may well not be sustained in the current year. In fact, it was pointed out in the Steel Industry Authority report that in the 1984-85 financial year there had been a noticeable decline in domestic sales and a very substantial increase in exports in that financial year. In fact, exports in 1984-85 rose from 778,000 tonnes to 1,047,000 tonnes. That is a very considerable increase. As I said, this is revealed in the Steel Industry Authority report. It involves concurrently a 5 per cent decrease in domestic dispatches and a 54 per cent increase in export sales, when compared with the figures for the previous year. This shift in the sales pattern was most noticeable during the first half of 1985-that is, the second half of the financial year-when domestic dispatches were relatively low and export sales were substantially greater than at any time since the commencement of the steel industry plan. The report suggests, of course, that the devaluation of the Australian dollar had helped to increase the overseas sales by the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd, which are now running at about 21 per cent of output compared to 16 per cent of output in 1983-84.

The interesting question that emerges in terms in Australia's balance of payments is that BHP's ability to satisfy an increase in its sales to both markets is limited, given that it is currently operating at close to its nominal capacity. That obviously means that if the increase in the domestic economy's activity, which the Government tells us is taking place at a rapid-in fact, the Government now says too rapid-rate, obviously, domestic demand for steel will increase and the capacity of BHP to export will be diminished, with a consequential impact in the remainder of this financial year on our balance of payments figures. I mention that because this is obviously another of the many problems that this Government faces in getting anywhere near its balance of payments target for the year, which, as the Senate is aware, is a deficit of only $10,700m, when clearly it appears to be heading to around the $12,000m to $12.5 billion mark.

The other point I make in regard to the steel industry is to note the enormous investment that BHP is now making in this industry, particularly in the Illawarra region. This is another problem which the Government must face. It is a problem in the sense that this massive investment is bringing with it a reduction in the levels of employment. In other words, this industry has to become more efficient. It is doing so, but the Government cannot hope to see any significant increases in employment as a result. I believe that is true of much of the investment going on in Australia at the moment. There are, however, some matters of concern to me that emerge from this major increase in investment. The Steel Industry Authority report reveals that recent public announcements by BHP indicate that total investment in steel during the life of the steel industry plan may be about $1,200m to $1,300m. The majority of the proposed capital expenditure is to be undertaken, I am glad to say, at the Port Kembla steelworks. This investment program is aimed primarily at increasing efficiency but not capacity. So the Government cannot look, as I said, to great increases in exports while local demand is increasing. The major benefits for the industry from the investment, the report states, will be apparent when the new continuous casting plants at Port Kembla and Newcastle and improvements to product mills are completed in 1987.

It is worth while then to look at what this investment has done so far for productivity. The report lists about $500m of expenditure undertaken or under way in Port Kembla. Yet in the last six months we have seen only a 1.6 per cent increase in productivity growth, in terms of hours per unit of output. In the six months to June 1984 there had been a 19.5 per cent increase due largely to the closure of so many of the old and inefficient blast furnaces. As a result, of course, there were the massive reductions in employment during the period preceding the six months to June, in fact, probably starting in 1982, at Port Kembla. I remind the House, of course, that the current Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), along with the current Minister for Housing and Construction (Mr West), attended a rally in my area when I was the member for Macarthur. He gave an undertaking to the people in that region just before the 1983 election that there would be no more sackings in the steel industry and no more retrenchments in the coal industry. The record shows the many thousands of people who are no longer employed in that industry. This report reveals a reduction of about 2,000 in the steel industry work force within the last two years.

But the issue that I think is significant is that there is still a massive need to increase productivity in the Australian steel industry. This enormous expenditure, hopefully, will do so. The Steel Industry Authority report, for example, pointed out that at Port Kembla the figure for tonnes per man-year is about 294, but in the British steel industry's Llanwern plant the figure is 420 tonnes per man-year; in Port Talbot in the United Kingdom it is 389 tonnes a year. All these figures are way above those for Australia. Of course, if we look at the figures in the United States, we see that, at the Bethlehem steel works the figure is 389 tonnes and at the Kimitsu plant in Japan the figure is 374 tonnes. So our performance is still obviously way behind.

I commend BHP for its massive expansion in respect of equipment. I regret that the people of the region were deceived by the leaders of the present Government when they were in opposition about the manning and employment levels that would apply in the steel industry under a Labor government. Those people were obviously misled grievously. Nonetheless, the consequences for the steel industry and for Australia as a whole have been a massive upgrading and improvement in the steel industry. I must say that I commend the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button), who is at the table, for the role he played in that massive improvement which is certainly to the benefit of the region in which I have my electorate office. I commend BHP for what it is undertaking.
I should not conclude my speech without commending the more responsible members of the union movement who have in fact reduced their level of industrial unrest in the region.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not their level of industrial unrest; it is the level of industrial unrest. It takes two to tango, you know.

—The Minister makes the reasonable point that it takes two people to have a dispute. I must say from my experience in the region that there has been an incredible level of industrial unrest. The Minister will remember the dispute at Port Kembla when a tug boat captain clocked one of his deckhands. The harbour was tied up for a long time as a result of a dispute that had absolutely nothing to do with BHP. The two who tangoed were members of different unions. That has been one of the major problems in that area. The Minister's interjection, while being right in theory, is totally wrong in practice. There has been far too much reckless and nonsensical industrial disputation in that area and that is one of the reasons the industry was faced with serious problems.

SPEECH.PARA: I commend those members of the union movement who have recognised the folly of their past practices and who now, having seen the massive reductions in employment that have followed, are doing what I believe is the right thing. I hope that both the employers and the employees contine to do the right thing even though, as the figures clearly show, the more the industry upgrades and modernises its plant the less will be its demand for labour.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank honourable senators for their contributions to this debate. I should point out that I heard only what was said by the last speaker, Senator Michael Baume. I think the honourable senator would be well advised to compare notes with Senator Puplick who made a totally different speech about the Steel Industry Authority report when that report was debated in the Parliament earlier today. It would be helpful if he did that. I think that Senator Baume is wrong about a number of stroppy allegatioins he made. He says that there have been retrenchments in the steel industry. There have been no retrenchments in the steel industry since the steel plan was introduced.
—What about since March 1983?
—Yes, there have been retrenchments since March 1983.
—That was the election date.
—I understand that. The essence of what the Government said in opposition was that it would stop the rot as far as disemployment in the steel industry was concerned, and that happened.
—How many thousands of workers later?

—Most of the workers were thrown out of the steel industry in 1982. The honourable senator would probably remember that, even though he was not here at the time. A number of other suggestions have been made in terms of comparing productivity figures in various countries and so on. I think the more important comparison is the condition of the Australian steel industry compared with the condition, for example, of Bethlehem Steel in the United States of America, to which the honourable senator referred. I would put my two bob into the Australian steel industry rather than Bethlehem Steel any day. In fact, there are very grave dangers in comparing international productivity figures because the statistics are compiled on totally different bases. Some steel industries include all the management and all the white collar staff in the productivity figures. The Australian industry, for example, does not.

SPEECH.PARA: The other important consideration which Senator Baume raised is the question of industrial disputes. I do not think he referred to the figures in the Steel Industry Authority report on the reduction in industrial disputes. Another interesting comparison which he might like to make, if he is a student of the steel industry, is wages in the steel industry in Australia compared with other industries overseas. From recollection, the more dramatic figures are that Australian steel workers are paid about $13.50 to $14 something an hour. Korean steel workers are paid about $4 an hour, United States steel workers about $28 an hour and British steel workers about $10 an hour. I think it will be found--

TALK.START.PARA: —And the Japanese about $14.
—Yes, more than us.
—The Japanese are about the same.

—I agree, they are about the same. But they are, in fact, ahead of us in terms of wages. So the comparisons are fairly dramatic and stark. It is interesting to find that we are at the bottom end of the pecking order in terms of wages, and not at the top end which is occupied by the Americans and some Europeans.
—Except the British.
—I said `some Europeans'. I have never regarded the British as Europeans. This is not the appropriate time to debate these matters. I thank honourable senators for their contributions.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 10 September 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How much money has been spent on restoration and renovation of the Air Force Field Office at 155 Barton Terrace, North Adelaide.
(2) Was this work done in accordance with National Trust criteria.
(3) Is the Department of Defence considering, or in the process of, selling the Barton Terrace property; if so, what price does it anticipate the property will bring.
(4) Is the Department intending to rent other premises for the Air Office in South Australia; if so, where, and what annual rental.
(b) renting rather than purchasing new premises.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Approximately $172,000 has been spent on repairs and maintenance to the Air Force property at 155 Barton Terrace, North Adelaide, since it was acquired by the RAAF in 1950. A further $25,000 is planned to be spent in 1985-86.
(2) Since the property was entered on the Register of the National Estate, all repair work has been agreed by the National Trust.

(3) The Department of Defence is considering alternative accommodation arrangements. If this occurs, the Department of Local Government and Administrative Services would arrange for valuation of the Barton Terrace property and its disposal.
(4) No decision has yet been taken to rent other premises.

(5) (a) If a decision to release the Barton Terrace property is made, it will be because the RAAF's accommodation needs can be met more economically in other premises; (b) No decision has yet been made to rent or purchase new premises.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Sanders Sen N.K.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment, upon notice, on 10 September 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Will the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment, following the Resolution passed by the State Council of the Queensland Division of the Australian Labor Party, calling for the nomination by the Federal Government of the Queensland Wet Tropical Rain- forests for World Heritage Listing, take action to ensure that this area is nominated on the World Heritage list.

(2) Is the timber of the rain-forest to be used in the construction of the new Parliament House; if so, can this be taken as an indication that the Government intends to ignore the Resolution on rain-forests of the Queensland State Council of the Australian Labor Party.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Under an agreement reached by the Council of Nature Conservation Ministers (CONCOM), the Commonwealth Government has written to State and Territory Governments inviting them to submit suggestions for places to be examined with a view to possible future nominations to the World Heritage List. Queensland has responded and advised that it does not wish to have any places in Queensland nominated for the World Heritage List. In this connection, the Commonwealth Government has indicated that it will not take unilateral action to nominate areas for World Heritage listing. The Government is committed to the preservation of both our natural and cultural heritage and it is considered that these aims can best be achieved through co-operation and consultation rather than conflict and confrontation. The recently released report on `Rainforest Conservation in Australia' which was prepared in collaboration between groups holding strong and diverse opinions on a complex environmental issue, exemplifies the value of co-operation and consultation.

(2) On 22 September 1985 the Speaker of the House of Representatives and the President of the Senate wrote jointly to all Members and Senators concerning the use of rainforest timbers in the construction of the new Parliament House.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 12 September 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: Have members of the Central Tablelands No Base Committee been attempting for some time to see the Minister for Defence to discuss the latest developments in the acquisition of land in the Orange-Bathurst area; if so, have meetings been held, if not, when will the Minister be available to discuss the matter with these people.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: Approaches have been made on a number of occasions by the Central Tablelands No Base Committee with a view to discussing the proposal for a Schools Complex to be located in the Orange-Bathurst area. The group has been advised that there seems little value in a meeting until the results of the environmental studies are available. At that stage all parties concerned will be in a position to discuss the matter in a properly informed way.

The No Base Central Tablelands Committee has every opportunity to make its views known to the consultants undertaking those studies, and to the Senate Foreign Affairs and Defence Committee which is now to inquire into the proposal.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 12 September 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is there extreme shortage of 7.62 mm and 5.56 mm calibre military ammunition.
(2) Has the next two years' supply run of 7.62 mm ammunition been rejected because of faulty brass case wall construction.
(3) Is the newer, smaller 5.56 mm calibre fully imported and none of this calibre yet manufactured in Australia.

(4) Are Army units storing their practice ammunition and have Reserve Forces in some units been advised to purchase ammunition privately, with the result that many recruits have not been able to qualify with arms.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) There are no problems in meeting Army's present capability and training requirements in any configuration of either 7.62 or 5.56 calibre ammunition.
(2) No 7.62 mm ammunition has been rejected recently for problems of cartridge case wall thickness nor are such problems anticipated.

(3) No 5.56 mm ammunition is manufactured in Australia at present. However, with the proposed adoption by Army of weapons of this calibre local production of 5.56 mm ammunition is also proposed and planning for production has commenced.

(4) See (1) above. For ammunition in excess of those requirements existing regulations allow units to store ammunition, including practice ammunition provided suitable approved storage facilities exist.
Army reserve units have not been advised to purchase ammunition privately nor are there any known instances of recruits being unable to qualify with arms due to lack of ammunition.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 17 September 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: Has the Department of Defence increased home rental rates over the past years for housing provided to: (a) Royal Australian Navy personnel; (b) Australian Army personnel; and (c) Royal Australian Air Force personnel; if so, have any such rises been of a comparable percentage to the Consumer Price Index; if not what have they been.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The present rent setting policy was determined in 1981 and provides that a review of married quarter rentals be undertaken annually but not earlier than November each year. The policy provides for changes in rent levels, where indicated, to be implemented in the following April.

The policy provides for rents to be reviewed by reference to a basket of factors which includes changes in rents in the private rental market, movements in the aggregate costs of providing married quarters, movements in community housing costs, movements in Defence Force salaries and movements in rents charged to tenants of other Commonwealth owned houses. Any changes in the quantum of rentals which result from an annual review are the consequence of a consideration of the totality of these factors.

Rent variations implemented in April of each year following the three most recent reviews were NIL in 1983, 11% in 1984 and 6.9% in 1985. In 1982, 1983 and 1984 the Housing Component of the Consumer Price Index was respectively 11.1%, 10.5% and 7.1%, while the `All Groups' component for the same years was 10.4%, 11.5% and 6.9%.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Kilgariff Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment, upon notice, on 16 September 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is it the Government's intention to declare the Gimbat and Goodparla Pastoral Leases as an extension of the Kakadu National Park, despite the historical existence of mineralisation in the area and the recent discovery of a major gold deposit at Coronation Hill.

(2) Will the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment guarantee that the development of the ore body discovered at Coronation Hill will be allowed to proceed, given that the ore is on Commonwealth land; if so, under what legislation will the development be allowed to proceed; if not, under existing legislation, is it the Government's intention to legislate to allow development to proceed.

(3) Is it the Government's intention to permit further exploration outside the existing mineral leases, given that the whole area proposed to be declared a national park is highly prospective for gold, base metals and other minerals.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: I am advised as follows:

(1) The Government is currently addressing various matters associated with the incorporation of the Gimbat and Goodparla pastoral leases into Kakadu National Park. The Government is well aware of the mineralisation of the area and the gold deposit at Coronation Hill, just as it is of the conservation and recreational values and pastoral uses of the area. These aspects are being fully considered.

(2, 3) Until the Government has fully considered the matter I am not in a position to make any statement regarding development of the ore body at Coronation Hill or to advise on the Government's intentions regarding future exploration.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment, upon notice, on 15 October 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: Can the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment confirm that the Australia Council is regarded by the Federal Government as merely another Government body under direct ministerial control instead of being an independent body designed to promote Australian art as was originally intended.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The Australia Council was established under the Australia Council Act 1975 and is the Government's arts funding agency. The powers and functions of the Council together with the relationship between the Council and the Government are set out in the present legislative arrangements.
